Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 10. On the copolymerization of methacrylic acid with styrene
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free radical copolymerization of methacrylic acid (MA) with styrene (St) at 60°C, initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) is carried out in hydrogen‐bond forming solvents and in solvents not capable of forming hydrogen bonds but exhibiting different dielectric constants. The influence of the solvent on copolymerization reactivity ratios, rate of polymerization, composition, molecular weight and polydispersity of the copolymers obtained is shown. The reactivity ratios of methacrylic acid <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> and of styrene <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> are determined by two different methods with good agreement. The values obtained by the Kelen‐Tüdös method are as follows:
<jats:list list-type="simple">
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in carbon tetrachloride: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,54 ± 0,01; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,06 ± 0,03;</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in chloroform: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,51 ± 0,01; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,08 ± 0,03;</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetone: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,43 ± 0,00; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,65 ± 0,02;</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in 1,4‐dioxane: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,41 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,59 ± 0,05;</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetonitrile: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,06 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,29 ± 0,00.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list></jats:p><jats:p>Changes of reactivity ratios depending on the medium are explained on the basis of the results from IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy and gel permeation chromatography (GPC).</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of methacrylic acid–ethyl acrylate copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methacrylic acid (MAA) and ethyl acrylate (EA) was performed in aqueous medium in the presence of an emulsifier with MAA as the major component (53.7–82.3 mol %). Emulsion stability was studied as a function of concentration and the nature of the emulsifier (ionic or nonionic). Copolymers were characterized using IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra of MAA–EA copolymers have been discussed in terms of their triad monomer sequence distributions. Reactivity ratios of the MAA–EA pair were determined using a nonlinear least‐square errors in variables method. Partition of the monomers in aqueous and organic phases was studied using a gas chromatographic technique. A two‐loci polymerization mechanism was proposed on the basis of this partition behavior and the calculated composition of the oligomeric radicals formed in the initial stages of polymerization. © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of 2‐ethylacrylic acid and methacrylic acid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of 2‐ethylacrylic acid (EAA) and methacrylic acid (MAA) were prepared in bulk and in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide (DMF). Although precipitation of the copolymers was observed in bulk, the reaction mixtures remained apparently homogeneous in DMF. Best‐fit terminal‐model reactivity ratios were determined by a nonlinear least squares technique to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAA</jats:sub> = 1.14 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>EAA</jats:sub> = 0.23 in bulk, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAA</jats:sub> = 1.91 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>EAA</jats:sub> = 0.09 in 50% DMF solution. Examination of <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra provided convincing evidence for the formation of statistical copolymers. Copolymerizations richer in MAA provided copolymers of higher molecular weights.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Relative reactivity ratios for two new 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relative reactivity ratios in free‐radical, emulsion copolymerizations for the systems 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methyl isopropenyl ketone and 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methacrylic acid were found to be 3.6 and 0.1 and 2.68 and 0.15, respectively. Consequently, copolymers are formed substantially richer in 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene units than the comonomer feed, have little alternation tendency, and do not form azeotropes. Distributions of monomer units in the copolymers are described.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Neue photoreaktive Polymere mit seitenständigen Dimethylmaleinimid‐Gruppen. I. Radikalische homo‐und copolymerisation von N‐(5‐methyl‐3‐oxa‐4‐oxo‐hexen‐5‐yl)‐dimethylmaleinimid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Homopolymerisation von N‐(5‐Methyl‐3‐oxa‐4‐hexen‐5‐yl)‐dimethylmaleinimid (DMI‐MA) führt zu linearen Polymethylmethacrylaten mit seitenständigen lichtvernetzbaren Dimethylmaleinimid‐Gruppen. Dabei nimmt die CC Doppelbindung des Imidylrestes infolge sterischer Hinderung durch die beiden Methylsubstituenten, selbst bei Umsätzen von über 90%, nicht an der Reaktion teil. Für die Homopolymerisation wurde die Polymerisationsgeschwindigkeitskonstante bestimmt zu k<jats:sub>p</jats:sub>/k<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00033146:media:APMC051150114:tex2gif-stack-1" /> = 2,0 – 2,2·10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup>(65°C, Toluol, AIBN); die Aktivierungsenergie beträgt E<jats:sub>a</jats:sub> = 62,36 ± 2 kJ/mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>.</jats:p><jats:p>Aus den Copolymerisationen der Monomerpaare DMI‐MA/Methacrylsäure (MAS), DMI‐MA/Methylmethacrylat (MMA) und DMI‐MA/Ethylacrylat (EA) ergaben sich folgende Copolymerisationsparameter: DMI‐MA (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) : MAS (r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) = 1,36 ± 0,06 : 0,77 ± 0,06; DMI‐MA (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) : MMA (r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) = 1,16 ± 0,17 : 0,475 ± 0,17 und DMI‐MA (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) : EA (r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) = 1,60 ± 0,15 : 0,44 ± 0,15.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of unsaturated carboxylic acids with styrene and an unsaturated tertiary amine in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization parameters of 2‐acryloyoxybenzoic (AOB) and 2‐methacryloyloxybenzoic (MOB) acids, methyl 2‐methacryloyloxybenzoate (MMOB), and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenyl‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate (MPAM) with styrene in benzene solution were determined and used in the calculation of the Alfrey‐Price copolymerization constants <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> for AOB, MOB, MMOB, and MPAM. Using <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> thus determined and the corresponding tabulated values for methacrylic acid (MAA), the copolymerization parameters of pairs AOB‐MPAM, MOB‐MPAM, MMOB‐MPAM, and MAA‐MPAM were calculated. They are compared with those determined by the copolymerization of these pairs in which the interaction of functional groups on comonomers plays a role.</jats:p>

Title: Study of the kinetics of polymerization and copolymerization of methacrylic acid sulpholanate
The influence of molecular interactions on polymerization—IV
General conclusions about the copolymerization of ethylene with other monomers by free radical catalysis
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The behavior of ethylene in copolymerization with methyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, diethyl fumarate, and diethyl maleate was investigated, and reactivity ratios for these systems reported. Significant deviations of all systems investigated, except ethylene–vinyl acetate, from the conventional copolymerization equation are noted and interpreted on the basis of substantial penultimate and penpenultimate effects. The consistency of the reactivity ratios developed in the systems ethylene–methyl acrylate and ethylene–methyl methacrylate with reported values for methyl acrylate–methyl methacrylate is shown by application of the relationship <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ab</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>bc</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ca</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ac</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>cb</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ba</jats:sub>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Radical copolymerization of ethylene with vinyl phosphonates under pressure
Study of radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with ethylene in suspension
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene (TFE) with ethylene (E) was initiated by 2,2′‐azo‐bis‐isobutyronitrile in batch and semibatch operation. The effect of reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, stirring speed, molar ratio of monomers, etc.) on copolymerization rate and copolymer molecular weight was studied. The highest reaction rate was observed at TFE content over 70 mol % and was found to be proportional to initiator concentration and total monomer content by powers of 0.9 and 1.54, respectively. These dependencies were attributed to the heterophase character of the copolymerization.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and overall activation energy of the reaction were determined. The effect of the monomer composition on the distribution of monomer units in the copolymer chain was studied. Kinetic mechanism of the copolymerization was suggested.</jats:p><jats:p>Some of the basic physical properties and chemical resistance of the alternating copolymers synthesized were also determined. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization studies. III. Reactivity ratios of model ethylene copolymerizations and their use in Q–e calculations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of ethylene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, vinyl chloride, vinyl acetate, and vinyl fluoride have been measured at 1000 atm. The respective values and the experimental temperatures are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 11.9, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, = 0.03, 70°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.6, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.24, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.07, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.39, 160°C. Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethylene calculated from these reactivity ratios, uncorrected for differences in reaction pressure, are 0.03 and −0.43, respectively. New <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub>) for these four comonomers were calculated on the basis of ethylene rather than styrene as the reference monomer. Assuming that the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values for ethylene are 1.0 and zero, respectively, the monomer's <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> value are as follows: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, 33.3, + 1.02; vinyl chloride, 4.2, + 0.37; vinyl acetate, 0.93, ∼0; vinyl fluoride, 0.25, + 0.6. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values give calculated reactivity ratios which are in reasonable agreement with experimental ones. Good agreement is also obtained when the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> value for the vinyl acetate/ethylene copolymerization is compared with the directly determined rate constant ratio for the addition of an ethyl radical to ethylene and to vinyl acetate, respectively, calculated from previously published data.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Study of radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with ethylene in bulk
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of tetrafluorethylene (TFE) with ethylene (E) by azo‐<jats:italic>bis</jats:italic>‐iso‐butyronitrile in the temperature interval 333–363 K, monomer pressure from 3.0 to 7.0 MPa at TFE/E molar ratio from 77/23 to 23/77 in bulk was carried out. The effect of reaction conditions on the yield, molecular weight, and polymer composition of copolymer synthesized was studied. White powdery alternating copolymers were obtained at TFE content in the monomer mixture from 65 to 85 mol %. Copolymerization rate <jats:italic>R</jats:italic> was described by the equation <jats:italic>R</jats:italic> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:sub>[ln] [Σ <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>]<jats:sup>1.3</jats:sup> which was related to the heterophase character of the reaction. The reactivity ratio of TFE and E (0.067 ± 0.12 and 0.52 ± 0.18, respectively) and apparent activation energy <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> = 135 kJ/mol were found. The TFE and E block formation probabilities were calculated and compared with IR spectroscopy data. Melting point, entropy, and enthalpy of fusion of the entirely alternating copolymers were determined. Some of the basic properties of the alternating copolymers obtained were also studied. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: RADIKALISCHE COPOLYMERISATION VON ETHYLEN MIT SALZEN DER METHACRYLSÄURE UNTER HOCHDRUCK
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In order to prepare ionomers, the radical copolymerisation of ethylene with salts of methacrylic acid was investigated. The polymerisation tests were performed in a continuously operated stirred autoclave at 1800 bar, 190 to 240°C and a residence time of 60 sec. The concentration of methacrylate in the feed was varied between 0, 3 and 3, 4 wt%. For comparison ethylene homopolymers were prepared.</jats:p><jats:p>From the polymerisation tests the conversion was determined. The resulting copolymers were analysed for their composition to calculate the reactivity ratios. Furthermore density, crystallinity and melt flow index were measured.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymers of vinyl chloride and vinylidene chloride with some acid chlorides
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Vinyl chloride and vinylidene chloride were copolymerized with 10‐acryloxydecanoyl chloride and 12‐acryloxystearoyl chloride by use of free‐radical initiator in solution to obtain copolymers with active chlorine groups. Alternative routes for making such copolymers which consisted of making the corresponding acrylic acid or acrylyl chloride copolymers, followed by reaction with hydroxy acid and finally conversion to the acid chloride by treatment with thionyl chloride, were investigated. The monomer reactivity ratios for the radical copolymerization of vinyl chloride (VCI) and vinylidene chloride (VCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with acrylic acid (AA) and acrylyl chloride (ACI) were determined: VCI–AA, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.025, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 6.40; VCl–ACl, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.017, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.65; VCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>–AA, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.46, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.26; VCl–ACl, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.50, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.12.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Experimental study of copolymerization. II
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In order to study further the effect of structure on monomer reactivities in copolymerization the copolymer composition as a function of initial monomer mixture composition has been determined for the following monomer pairs: vinyl acetate–vinyl chloride, ethyl methacrylate–vinylidene chloride, butyl methacrylate–vinylidene chloride, vinyl acetate–tetrachloroethylene, allyl chloride–vinylidene chloride, vinyl acetate–vinylidenechloride, methyl methacrylate–vinyl chloride, pentene‐1–vinyl chloride, allyl chloride–vinyl acetate, methyl methacrylate–2,5‐di‐chlorostyrene, vinyl chloride–vinylidene chloride, and vinyl chloride–dioctyl maleate.</jats:p>

Title: High Pressure Copolymerization of Styrene and Vinyl Acetate with Vinyl Chloride
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The radical copolymerization of vinyl chloride and styrene, and that of vinyl chloride and vinyl acetate, were investigated in an acetone solution at 50°C under high pressures of up to 3000 kg/cm2. The monomer reactivity ratios of these copolymers were not affected by the pressure, while their molecular weights and overall rates of copolymerization increased with the pressure. The increments of the four rate constants of the growing chain of copolymerization (k11,k12,k21, and k22) with the pressure are all of the same order. In such a case, ΔV*11 is ΔV*12, and ΔV*22 is ΔV*21 (ΔV*ij is the activation volume in which the i radical reacted with the j monomer). The conclusion drawn from our previous works, that the monomer reactivity ratios of the copolymerization between nonconjugated monomers are independent of the pressure was supported by the experimental results of this report.</jats:p>
Journal: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan

Title: Vitesse de polymérisation et de copolymérisation de l'acétate d'isopropényle
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>En présence de peroxyde de benzoyle, l'acétate d'isopropényle polymérise de la même facon que l'acétate d'allyle. Son comportement lors de la copolymérisation avec l'acétate de vinyle, le chlorure de vinyle et le méthacrylate de méthyle montre que ce monomère possède une réactivité générale semblable à celle de l'acétate de vinyle. Le caractère négatif de la double soudure est plus prononcé (−0.8). Ces copolymérisations sont caractérisées par un important transfert de chaîne, dû à la présence de l'acétate d'isopropényle. A l'égard du styrène, l'acétate d'isopropényle se comporte comme un solvant; il n'y a ni copolymérisation, ni transfert de chaîne.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymérisation de l'Anhydride Maléique avec Différents Monomères Vinyliques
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Mischpolymerisation von Maleinsaeure Anydrid mit verschiedenen Vinyl‐Verbindungen wie Methakrylsaeure, Methylester, Vinylchlorid, Vinylazetat und Isopropenylazetat wurde untersucht. Die Verhaeltnisse der Geschwindigkeits‐Konstanten <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> und <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> wurden fuer jeden dieser Faelle festgestellt. Die Mischpolymerisation mit Monomeren, die eine elektronreiche Doppelverbindung enthalten, zeichnet sich durch eine hohe Selektivitaet aus. In diesen Faellen koennen die Ergebnisse nicht gaenzlich durch das Alfrey‐Price Schema erklaert werden.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization studies. IV. Transannular copolymerization of bicyclo[2.2.1] hepta‐2,5‐diene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Bicyclo[2.2.1]hepta‐2,5‐diene, in the presence of free‐radical initiators, homopolymerizes to a low molecular weight, soluble polymer containing both 3,5‐disubstituted nortricyclene and 5,6‐disubstituted bicyclo [2.2.1] hept‐2‐ene units in the polymer backbone. When the bicycloheptadiene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is copolymerized with vinyl chloride, vinylidene chloride, acrylonitrile, ethyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate, only the transannular product, 3,5‐disubstituted nortricyclene, is found in the high molecular weight copolymers. Reactivity ratios for the above mentioned copolymerizations at 50°C. are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.74, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.35; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.41, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.08; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.67, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.08; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> =10.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0; respectively. From these data, the Q and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for bicyclo[2.2.l]hepta‐2,5‐diene average 0.09 and −1.04, respectively.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Cyclocopolymerization of Diallyl Phthalate with Vinyl Chloride
Vinyl polymerization. XCII. Polymerization of propenyl chloride isomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The effect of the substituent on polymerization of isopropenyl chloride (IPC), <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>‐propenyl chloride (CPC), and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐propenyl chloride (TPC) has been investigated. These monomers homopolymerized only very slightly in the presence of radical or ionic catalyst, and only a low molecular weight polymer of IPC was isolated. However, these monomers copolymerized with radical initiator with vinyl acetate, vinyl chloride, and acrylonitrile, and their reactivities towards the poly(vinyl acetate) radical decreased in order of IPC ≫ TPC ≥ CPC. The <jats:italic>Q, e</jats:italic> values for the monomers were estimated as follows: for IPC, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.06, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.85; for CPC, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.005, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −1.66; for TPC. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.009, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −1.33. Further results on copolymerization with maleic anhydride indicated that the steric effect of the substituent for these monomers increased in order IPC ≪ TPC ≤ CPC. On radical polymerization of IPC, its degradative chain transfer reactivity was suggested to be also significant.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: High resolution NMR studies on sequence distribution of vinylidene chloride copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Sequence distributions of several radical copolymers of vinylidene chloride were examined by NMR spectroscopy, including methyl methacrylate, benzyl methacrylate, methaeryloyl chloride, methyl acrylate, α‐methylstyrene, styrene, and vinyl acetate as comonomers. Except for the α‐methylstyrene and styrene systems, some of the diad, triad, and tetrad sequences were observed in the CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and αCH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> resonances and are discussed in the light of the usual copolymerization theory.</jats:p>

Title: Vinyl Polymerization. 131. Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with N-Methylol-acrylamide
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with N-(4-Substituted phenyl)maleimide
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Vinyl Polymerization
Studies on the Copolymerization of Aldehydes
Kinetics of copolymerization of ethylene and vinyl chloride
Polymerization and Copolymerization of 2-Methyl-and 2-Phenyl-N-Vinyl Imidazole
Studies on Polymerization and Polymers of Itaconic Acid Derivatives
Copolymerizations of vinyl silanes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A brief experimental investigation was made of the copolymerization of twelve alkoxysilanes with monochlorostyrene, vinyl chloride, and acrylonitrile. These new monomers include vinyltrimethoxy‐, vinyltriethoxy‐, vinyltriisoproxy‐, vinylmethyldiethoxy‐, vinylethyldiethoxy‐, and vinylphenyldiethoxy‐silanes as well as allyl‐, propenyl‐, 2‐butenyl‐, Δ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup>‐cyclohexenyl‐, 6‐triethoxysilylbicyclo [2.2.1]heptane‐2, and α‐chlorovinyl‐triethoxysilanes. No copolymerization took place with monochlorostyrene. In the copolymerizations with vinyl chloride, and with acrylonitrile, the reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was assumed to be zero and the value of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> determined.</jats:p>

Title: Nitrogen‐containing monomers. II. Reactivity ratios of n‐vinyloxazolidone and N‐vinylpyrrolidone with vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyloxazolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, decyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and vinyl chloride have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values calculated. Reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and vinyl acetate have also been determined and the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values determined. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinyloxazolidone was found to be similar but less reactive than <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone as a comonomer; however, the properties of the resultant copolymers differed appreciably.</jats:p>

Title: The Cyclocopolymerization of Triallyl Citrate with Several Vinyl Monomers
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Triallyl citrate (TAC) was copolymerized with allyl benzoate (ABz), vinyl acetate (VAc), vinyl chloride (VC), acrylonitrile (AN), and styrene (St) at 60°C with benzoyl peroxide or 2,2′,-azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator; it was considered kinetically in terms of cyclocopolymerization. The following monomer reactivity ratios were obtained: VAc: r1=1.29, r2=0.76, rc=0.61; ABz: r1=1.63, r2=1.10, rc=0.47; VC: r1=0.40; r2=1.90, rc=0.31; AN: r1=0.01, r2=8.7; St: r1=0.03, r2=53.0, where r1, rc and r2 denote the monomer reactivity ratio of the uncyclized, cyclized, and monovinyl radicals respectively. In the copolymerization of TAC with AN, the penultimate effect was also observed: r1=r1′=0.01, r2=k122⁄k121=11, r2′=k222⁄k221=5.</jats:p>
Journal: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with N-n-Alkylmaleimide
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Radical copolymerization of acrylic monomers: 10. Copolymerization of ortho-methacryloyloxybenzoic acid with methyl methacrylate and vinyl chloride
Copolymerization of trialkyl aconitates with butadiene and some vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios have been determined for the copolymerization of trimethyl aconitate with butadiene, styrene, acrylonitrile, and vinyl chloride, and for triethyl aconitate with butadiene and styrene. The values obtained indicate that trialkyl aconitates are very reactive in free radical initiated copolymerizations. No copolymerizations of aconitic acid were realized. A copolymer of butadiene and trimethyl aconitate has been prepared in a modified Mutual recipe at 50°C. The copolymer shows fair oil resistance and tensile properties but the low‐temperature properties are poor. The temperature rise of trimethyl aconitate copolymer is possibly better than that of standard GR‐S made at 50°C.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with Acrolein and Crotonaldehyde
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Radical polymerization and copolymerization of some vinyl phosphates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Diethyl vinyl phosphate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>), diphenyl vinyl phosphate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), and phenyl divinyl phosphate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) were prepared, and their polymerization and copolymerization behaviors as well as the hydrolysis of the polymers obtained were investigated. The monomers <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> were homopolymerized to give low molecular weight polymers, probably as a result of high chain transfer reactivity to monomer. Although the monomer <jats:bold>3</jats:bold> gave a cross‐linked polymer, this polymerization was found to proceed mainly by a cyclopolymerization mechanism to give a polymer with a five‐membered ring unit which was readily hydrolyzed. The alkaline hydrolysis of poly(<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) occurred only partly and thus pure polyvinyl alcohol was not obtained. From the copolymerizations of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> with vinyl monomers such as vinyl chloride, the reactivities of these monomers were found to be somewhat lower than that of vinyl acetate.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. IX. A Comparison of Some cis and trans Isomers<sup>1,2</sup>
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Polymerisation of methyl trifluoroacrylate
Effect of the substituents on radical copolymerization of dialkyl fumarates with some vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of dialkyl fumarates (DRF) with various vinyl monomers was carried out in benzene at 60°C. The monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, were determined from the comonomer‐copolymer composition curves. The relative reactivity of DRFs with various ester substituents toward a polystyryl radical was revealed to depend on both steric and polar effects of the ester groups. It has also been clarified that α‐substituents of the polymer radical have a significant role in addition of DRF, from the comparison of the monomer reactivity ratios determined in copolymerizations with monosubstituted and 1,1‐disubstituted ethylenes. The absolute cross‐propagation rate constants were also evaluated and discussed. © 1992 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Zur Radikalischen Copolymerisation ungesättigter Isocyanate mit Vinylchlorid
Abstract: <jats:p><jats:bold>On the Free Radical Copolymerization of Unsaturated Isocyanates with Vinylchloride</jats:bold></jats:p><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of vinyl‐, isopropenyl‐ and p‐vinyl‐phenylisocyanate with vinylchloride in mass and tetrahydrofurane solution at 50°C is investigated. The incorporation of the isocyanate monomers in the copolymers is favoured. These monomers effect a great decrease of the rate of copolymerization and a crosslinking of the formed homo‐ and copolymers, whose extent depends on the kind and the quantity of the incorporated monomers. The crosslinking is caused by the forming of isocyanurate units.</jats:p>

Title: Some polymers and copolymers of vinyl ketostearates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Vinyl esters of 4‐ketostearic acid, 9(10)‐ketostearic acid, and 12‐ketostearic acid have been homopolymerized and copolymerized with vinyl chloride. Reactivity ratios have been determined for the three vinyl ketostearates with vinyl acetate and vinylidine chloride. Also reactivity ratios for the 4‐ and 10‐ketostearates with vinyl chloride and those of the 9(10)‐ketostearates and 12‐ketostearate with acrylonitrile were determined. The mechanical properties of typical vinyl chloride‐vinyl ketostearate copolymers have been examined and compared with a similar vinyl chloride‐vinyl stearate copolymer and with a plasticized vinyl chloride‐vinyl acetate copolymer. The copolymers of vinyl chloride with vinyl 9(10)‐ketostearate and with vinyl 12‐ketostearate compare favorably with the compolymer of vinyl chloride and vinyl stearate in general properties.</jats:p>

Title: Effects of complexing agents in radical copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with various monomers has been studied in presence of modifiers, i.e., complexing agents (CA): ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, AlBr<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, Al(C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>Cl, forming coordinate complexes with ester group of the monomer and of the propagating radical. The comonomers of the first group form complexes of similar structure and stability as MMA, methyl acrylate, or butyl acrylate. The comonomers of the second group do not form complexes with the modifiers (vinylidene chloride, 2,6‐dichlorostyrene, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene, styrene). For all systems studied the copolymer composition follows the Mayo‐Lewis equation. In the first group of the systems the effective reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) approach unity with increase of the CA molar content (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ≃ 1 at [(CA)/MMA] + [MA] ≥ 0,3) In the second group of the systems the values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> either increase to a limit value (at [CA]/[MMA] ≥ 0.3), pass through maximum, or decrease to a limiting value with the CA molar content. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> decrease in all systems. The character of variation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> has been explained in terms of effects of the CA's on reactivity of MMA and PMMA radical. The equations for the copolymer compositions in these systems have been derived.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: A revised Q–e diagram
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>New data are presented to establish the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of vinylidene chloride, acrylonitrile, and vinyl chloride relative to styrene as the reference monomer. Within the experimental error these values are shown to be entirely consistent with the observed copolymer compositions. Only the values for vinyl chloride are appreciably different from those published in the original paper of Alfrey and Price in 1947. With these better data it is hoped that renewed efforts will be made to place this empirical device on a sound theoretical basis.</jats:p>

Title: Polymerizable derivatives of long‐chain alcohols. II. Reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of some alkyl acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios were determined for the copolymerization of some alkyl acrylate esters and, respectively, acrylonitrile and vinylidene chloride. For acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), the values found were: for butyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.52 ± 0.03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.75 ± 0.18; for octyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.93 ± 0.08, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.83 ± 0.23; for octadecyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.74 ± 0.04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.68 ± 0.18. If it is assumed that there is no change in the magnitude of the kinetic constants with chain length, a value for the generalized alkyl acrylate and acrylonitrile may be calculated and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.61 ± 0.04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.50 ± 0.19. Values found with vinylidene chloride (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were: for butyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.10, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.83 ± 0.02; for octyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.87 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.70 ± 0.01; for octadecyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.91 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.01 ± 0.01. For the generalized alkyl acrylate, the calculated values were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.84 ± 0.01.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerisation of maleimide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The Q and e values for maleimide amount to 0.41 and 1.33 respectively.</jats:p><jats:p>The chemical reactivity and the IR‐spectrum of polymaleimide are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization behavior of N‐vinylcarbazole and other N‐vinyl monomers
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>N‐vinylcarbazole has been copolymerized with methyl methacrylate, methyl acrylate, styrene and vinylidene chloride. From the reactivity ratios found and from literature data, the Q and e values were calculated according to the A<jats:sc>LFREY</jats:sc>‐P<jats:sc>RICE</jats:sc> scheme.

Title: Copolymerization of Ethylene and Vinylidene Chlor ide Induced by γ-Rays
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of N‐octadecylacrylamide and N‐allylstearamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 60 ± 0.1°C. were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.44 ± 0.019, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10 ± 0.035; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.60, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.37 ± 0.008, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.438 ± 0.008; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.65, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.11 ± 0.045, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.027 ± 0.009; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.72, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12. The mean copolymerization parameters, therefore, were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.13. The reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ally lstearamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers, polymerized in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 80 ± 0.1°C. (except for vinyl acetate, polymerized in bulk at 70 ± 0.1°C.) were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.118 ± 0.084, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.61 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.058; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0 ± 0.136, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5.23 ± 0.067; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.028, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.80; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.0532 ± 0.012, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.740 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −1.18. The mean copolymerization parameters for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐allylstearamide were, therefore, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.59.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymérisation de la N‐vinyl‐2‐oxazolidinone
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>La N‐vinyl‐2‐oxazolidinone a été copolymérisée avec plusieurs monomères. Les paramètres r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> et r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ont été calculés:

Title: Über die copolymerisation des N‐vinylsuccinimids
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Es werden die Copolymerisationsparameter für die Copolymerisation des N‐Vinylsuccinimids (1) mit den folgenden Comonomeren (2) bestimmt: Styrol (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,07; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 10,5), Methylmethacrylat (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,064; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 9,5), Vinylidenchlorid (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,32; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1,44) und Vinylacetat (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6,1; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,14).</jats:p><jats:p>Aus den Copolymerisationsparametern werden die Q‐ und e‐Werte nach ALFREY und PRICE für N‐Vinylsuccinimid berechnet und mit den Werten verglichen, die für andere N‐Vinylmonomere ermittelt wurden.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of trialkyl aconitates with vinylidene chloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of trimethyl aconitate and vinylidene chloride have been determined. Some copolymers of vinylidene chloride with trimethyl, triethyl, and tri‐n‐butyl aconitate have been reported. The stabilizing effect of aconitic esters on the color of polyvinylidene chloride has been confirmed.</jats:p>

Title: Free-Radical Polymerization of 2-Phenyl-5-(4'-vinyl)phenyltetrazole. Reactivity Ratios and Q and e Values
Copolymerization. VI.<sup>1</sup> The Copolymerization of Chloroethylenes with other Monomers
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: THE POLYMERIZATION OF ISOPRENE AND 2, 3-DIMETHYLBUTADIENE AND COPOLYMERIZATION WITH STYRENE AT −18 °C. IN EMULSION
Abstract: <jats:p> The rate of polymerization increased with purification of the monomers. It was possible that the dienes formed cyclic compounds or dimers in side reactions. The 1,2 addition of the monomer decreased with decreasing polymerization temperature. A study was made of the copolymerization of isoprene and dimethylbutadiene with styrene at −18° C. From analyses of bound diene in the product at various conversions and initial diene to styrene ratios the reactivity ratios for these diene-styrene systems were calculated to be r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.30 ± 0.02 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.48 ± 0.01 for isoprene and styrene and r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.92 ± 0.02, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.42 ± 0.02 for dimethylbutadiene and styrene (styrene always being considered monomer 2). Q and e values from the Alfrey-Price equation were calculated as Q = 119 and e = −0.112 for isoprene and Q = 1.09 and e = −0.181 for dimethylbutadiene relative to Q = 1.0 and e = −0.8 for styrene. Fom these and the values previously determined for butadiene, reactivity ratios for all combinations of the three dienes were calculated. The chain transfer reaction between dienyl radicals and mixed tertiary mercaptans was studied and it was found that isoprenyl and dimethylbutadienyl radicals were much more reactive than butadienyl. The effect of this was illustrated by number and viscosity average molecular weights. Intrinsic viscosities of homo- and copolymers formed in a mercaptan-free recipe were measured and compared. </jats:p>

Title: Bulk copolymerization of phenylacetylene with methacrylonitrile and with isoprene
Polymerization of aromatic and heterocyclic vinyl compounds
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The polymerization of vinyl derivatives of naphthalene and of the heterocyclic series containing the atoms of nitrogen, oxygen and sulfur has been investigated. It is proved that an increase in the number of condensed rings in the radicals replacing the hydrogen atoms in the ethylene molecule, as well as the introduction of heteroatoms (nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur) into these radicals increase the polymerization ability of the above compounds.</jats:p>

Title: POLYMERIZATION OF 2-FLUOROBUTADIENE-1,3 AND PROPERTIES OF POLYMERS
Abstract: <jats:p> Fluorobutadiene has been copolymerized with styrene in emulsion at 5 °C. The rate of mercaptan consumption, rate of conversion, copolymer composition, and the intrinsic viscosity of the copolymer have been measured. Reactivity ratios and regulating indices were calculated for this temperature. Copolymerization reactions at 50 °C. were studied in solution, and the reactivity ratios calculated. These were, for the following monomers as monomer 2: styrene at 5 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.61 ± 0.24 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.16 ± 0.08; styrene at 50 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.55 ± 0.10 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.50 ± 0.10; acrylonitrile at 50 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.59 ± 0.10 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.07 ± 0.03; isoprene at 50 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.05±0.19 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.19 ± 0.10; α-methyl styrene at 50 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.77 ± 0.19 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.38 ± 0.11; and methyl methacrylate at 50 °C., r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.54 ± 0.08 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.64 ± 0.08. Polyfluorobutadiene has a cohesive energy density of 90–100 cal./cc., a second order transition point of −62.5 °C., and some units formed by 1,2 or 3,4 addition. </jats:p>

Title: CROSS-LINKING OF COPOLYMERS FROM METHYL VINYL KETONE AND n-BUTYL ACRYLATE
Abstract: <jats:p> Copolymers of n-butyl acrylate and methyl vinyl ketone can be cross-linked by a combination of sulphur and zinc oxide; the reaction is associated with the methyl vinyl ketone units in the polymer chain. From studies on the copolymers and model compounds, it is suggested that adjacent pairs or groups of methyl vinyl ketone units in the polymer cyclize to give αβ unsaturated ketone groups. These contain reactive hydrogen which is attacked by sulphur; disulphide or zinc mercaptide cross-links are then formed. Water is produced in the cyclization reaction and hydrolyzes some of the ester groups; additional cross-links are thus formed by reaction of the acid groups with zinc oxide. The ease of cyclization and, therefore, the extent of cross-linking is dependent on the method of preparing the copolymers, emulsion copolymers being much more reactive than those prepared in solution. A comparison has been made between the sulphur + zinc oxide system and other cross-linking agents which may be used for polyacrylates. </jats:p>

Title: Effect of pH on the reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of acrylic acid and acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The content of acrylic acid and acrylamide in their copolymers can be controlled by changing pH. The reactivity ratio of acrylic acid decreases with increasing pH, while the reactivity ratio of acrylamide increases with increasing pH. At low pH values, acrylamide is present in its protonated form which causes its reactivity to be low whereas at high pH values the reactivity of acrylic acid is decreased owing to its dissociation. When the monomer and radical approach each other, the acrylate anion becomes the least reactive species because of its symmetrical charge distribution, like charge repulsion and barium ion screening effect. HMO calculations were performed for models of all monomers and polymer radicals involved in copolymerizations. The experimental results concerning the reactivity of acrylic acid and acrylamide in copolymerization and the observed reactivity ratios were discussed on the basis of HMO calculations and resonance and Coulomb electrostatic effects. The observed reactivity ratios were correlated with the calculated differences in resonance energies computed for the models of transition states involved in copolymerizations.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Some aspects of inverse emulsion copolymerization of acrylamide with methacrylic acid
Solvent effects in radical copolymerization. I. Acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylamide has been free radical copolymerized with styrene and methyl methacrylate at 70°C in different solvents (dioxane, dioxane/ethanol mixture, ethanol). A strong influence of the solvent on the copolymer compositions has been observed; particularly copolymers richer in acrylamide have always been obtained in dioxane.</jats:p><jats:p>These results indicate that the nature of the solvent (polarity, dielectric constant <jats:italic>etc</jats:italic>.) could affect the polarity and the reactivity of the acrylamide double bond as well as the stability of the growing radical. Other factors are also discussed.</jats:p>

Title: The free radical copolymerization characteristics of α-methylene γ-butyrolactone
A novel synthetic procedure of vinylacetamide and its free radical polymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The pyrolysis of N‐(α‐methoxyethyl) acetamide, which was obtained by one‐step reaction of acetamide, acetaldehyde, and methanol, gave <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylacetamide (NVA) in a good yield. The polymerizability and copolymerizability of NVA were studied. Free radical polymerization was carried out in the presence of radical initiator or by γ‐ray irradiation. The monomer reactivity ratios of NVA were estimated in the copolymerization with acrylamide, vinyl acetate, and methyl methacrylate. The solvents were found to influence the monomer reactivity ratio. NVA showed a typical copolymerizability as nonconjugated vinyl monomer, and Q and e values were obtained in DMF as 0.16 and −1.57, respectively.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Reactivities of cis‐ and trans‐3‐substituted acrylic acids on copolymerization with acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Several pairs of <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>‐ and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐3‐substituted acrylic acids (3SAA) were copolymerized with acrylamide in order to determine the major factors affecting the relative reactivities of geometrical isomers of 1,2‐disubstituted ethylenes (1,2‐DE). The results were that the relative reactivity of <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic> isomer is larger than that of <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> isomer when one substituent is electron‐withdrawing and the other is electron‐donating. The <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> isomer is more reactive than the <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic> isomer when both substituents are electron‐withdrawing. A new method of reactivity comparison of <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>‐ and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,2‐DE is proposed in regard to the inductive substituent constant.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Sequence Determination in Acrylic Acid-Methyl Methacrylate Copolymers by 13C and 1H NMR Spectroscopy
Copolyméres ordinaires et Copolyméres greffés Structure de polyampholytes et Interactions acide‐base
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Des polyampholytes de structure interne nettement différente ont été synthétisés au départ d'acide acrylique et de 2‐vinylpyridine. Les uns ont été préparés par copolymérisation en solution d'acrylate d'éthyle et de 2‐vinylpyridine et saponification ultérieure du copolymère statistique obtenu; ces polyampholytes présentent une structure sensiblement alterne, ainsi qu'il ressort des paramétres de la copolymérisation (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ac</jats:sub>=0,19; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>vp</jats:sub>:0.23). Les autres polyampholytes ont été obtenus par polymérisation en bloc de 2‐vinylpyridine en présence de polyacrylate d'éthyle; les copolyméres greffés ainsi produits ont été séparés des deux homopolymères correspondants par précipitation fractionnée au départ de leur solution chloroformique par addition progressive d'éther de pétrole. L'hydrolyse acide de ces derniers copolyméres fournit des polyampholytes greffés, qui sont constitués d'une chaîne principale d'acide polyacrylique et de chaînes latérales de polyvinylpyridine. Les taux de greffage des fractions principales de ces polyampholytes s'élevaient à 37, 55 et 75 % de vinylpyridine.</jats:p><jats:p>Ces copolymères ordinaires et greffés ont été comparés entre eux en milieu acide et en milieu alcalin afin d'étudier l'influence de la répartition des charges sur leur comportement respectif, et en particulier, sur leur comportement viscosimétrique. La quaternation partielle (50 %) de ces copolymères a également été effectuée par réaction avec le bromure d'éthyle; la présence des groupes éthylpyridiniums augmente la solubilité de ces substances, et modifie leur comportement viscosimétrique en solution alcaline. Finalement ces copolyméres ordinaires et greffés ont été comparés à des mélanges de copolymères de la vinylpyrrolidone, à savoir des mélanges de co‐(vinylpyrrolidone‐acide acrylique)‐polymère et de co‐(vinylpyrrolidone‐vinylpyridine)‐polymères.</jats:p>

Title: Herstellung und Polymerisation von Carbamidsäurevinylestern
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Carbamidsäurevinylester wurden durch Dehydrohalogenierung der entsprechendes Carbamidsäure‐[β‐halogen‐äthylester] hergestellt. Die Homopolymerisation dieser Verbindungen und die Copolymerisation des Diäthylcarbamidsäurevinylesters mit Acrylsäure, Acrylsäuremethylester und Maleinsäureanhydrid wurden untersucht und hierfür die Copolymerisationsparameter bestimmt.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N‐vinylurethane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinylurethane (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), prepared by the method of Hart, has been copolymerized with vinylacetate vinylpyrrolidone, acrylic acid, and maleic anhydride. From the copolymerization reactivity ratios with vinyl acetate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.33) and with vinylpyrrolidone (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.42; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2) <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were evaluated, in agreement with the Alfrey‐Price equation, to 0.12 and −1.91, respectively. These results are compared to those of other <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐substituted monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Vinylhydroquinone. III. Copolymerization of vinylhydroquinone and vinyl monomers by tri‐n‐butylborane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of vinylhydroquinone (VHQ) and vinyl monomers, e.g., methyl methacrylate (MMA), 4‐vinyl‐pyridine (4VP), acrylamide (AA), and vinyl acetate (VAc), by tri‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylborane (TBB) was investigated in cyclohexanone at 30°C under nitrogen. VHQ is assumed to copolymerize with MMA, 4VP, and AA by vinyl polymerization. The following monomer reactivity ratios were obtained (VHQ = M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>): for MMA/VHQ/TBB, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.62, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.17; for 4VP/VHQ/TBB, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.57, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.05; for AA/VHQ/TBB, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.35, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.08. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of VHQ were estimated on the basis of these reactivity ratios as <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 1.4 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −;1.1, which are similar to those of styrene. This suggests that VHQ behaves like styrene rather than as an inhibitor in the TBB‐initiated copolymerization. No homopolymerization was observed either under nitrogen or in the presence of oxygen. The reaction mechanism is discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Copolymerization of vinylhydroquinone dibenzoate with acrylic and methacrylic acids
Polymères de la méthacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>La polymérisation de la méthacrylamide fournit des polymères, dont la teneur en azole est fonction de la température à laquelle la réaction a été menée; au‐dessus de 65°, le taux d'azote est trop faible, par suite de la mise en liberté d'ammoniaque. Cette réaction de désamination est catalysée par l'addition d'acide; l'énergie d'activation de cette réaction a été évaluée à 29 Kcal.</jats:p><jats:p>La constitution de ces polyméthacrylamides désaminées a été étudiée par comparaison avec des copolymères (acide‐amide méthacryliques).</jats:p><jats:p>La différence des propriétés de solubilité, de même que l'allure totalement différente des courbes de titrage conductimétrique, excluent une constitution similaire. Une structure imidifiée, formée aux dépens des fonctions amides préexistantes, répond aux propriétés de ces polyméthacrylamides, partiellement appauvries en azote.</jats:p><jats:p>Les valeurs des paramètres <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> et <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ont été déterminées dans le as de la copolymérisation (acide méthacrylique‐méthacrylamide); ils s'élèvent respectivement à 2 et 0,22 ± 0,02.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymérisation de dérivés méthacryliques
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Des expériences de copolymérisation de différents monomères méthacryliques ont été effectuées. L'interprétation de ces résultats au départ des équations d'Alfrey‐Price montre que la double soudure vinylique subit des modifications importantes quant à sa polarité et quant à sa réactivité générale. Le caractère électrophile des différents substituants peut se classer dans l'échelle suivante:</jats:p><jats:p>—CONH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> < —COOMe < —COOH < —CN</jats:p><jats:p>La validité des équations de départ est discutée, et restreint la valeur absolue des polarités obtenues.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effects in radical copolymerization III. Methacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of methacrylamide with styrene and methyl methacrylate has been investigated at 70°C in solvents having different dielectric constants. A strong influence of the solvent on the copolymerization parameters has been observed. Such behaviour is quite similar to that found by the same authors for acrylamide copolymerization and differs completely from that found for N.N‐dialkyl acrylamide. The influence of the solvent properties (polarity, dielectric constant <jats:italic>etc.</jats:italic>) on the amide‐enol equilibrium is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of some further monomer pairs
Kinetics of chlorotrifluoroethylene polymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>An exploratory investigation of the kinetics of the polymerization of chlorotrifluoroethylene (I) has been made. Experiments were conducted in bulk, in solution in several solvents, and in the presence of several comonomers. Acetyl peroxide (II) was found to be the most effective of common initiators and was used in most of the experiments. The sealed empoule technique was employed. The bulk polymerization of I is zero order to 60–80% conversion; the rate varies as the 0.7 to 0.8 power of the acetyl peroxide concentration, and the over‐all activation energy is 17 kcal./mole. The solution polymerization in benzene appears to be first order in monomer; in other solvents the order was not ascertained. The rate and activation energy in solution are solvent dependent and there appears to be an inverse relationship between the rate of polymerization of I in a solvent and the rate of decomposition of II in that solvent. The rate of decomposition of II was measured in a number of solvents and found to vary widely and to parallel, roughly, the rate of decomposition of benzoyl peroxide. The polymerization rate of I in solution is also <jats:italic>c.</jats:italic> 0.7 order in acetyl peroxide, but was 0.5 order in Porofor N in limited experiments. From copolymerization experiments with styrene, vinyl acetate and methyl methacrylate values of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> of 0.025, 0.025, and 0.016, and of <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> of 1.4, 2.0, 1.4, respectively, were inferred, in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme of Alfrey and Price. These results above are discussed in the light of polymerization theory.</jats:p>

Title: Preparation of amide and amine groups containing copolymers of methyl methacrylate and their performance in solid polymer composites
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methyl methacrylate (MMA) was copolymerized with acrylamide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylacrylamide, <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>‐dimethylacrylamide, 1‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone, 4‐vinylpyridine, and 2‐dimethylaminomethyl methacrylate in 1,4‐dioxane solution at 65°C, using AIBN as initiator, to yield copolymers with comonomer contents between about 5 and 50 mole‐%. The monomer reactivity ratios were evaluated. The copolymerizations are in general non‐azeotropic and non‐ideal. The amine group containing comonomers are preferentially incorporated in relation to MMA, but MMA is preferentially incorporated in relation to the amide group containing comonomers. The average molecular weights of the copolymers, with the exception of the <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>‐dimethylacrylamide copolymer, decrease with increasing comonomer concentration, especially in the case of the amine group containing comonomers. The increasing content of amide and amine group containing monomeric units in the copolymers influences the adsorption of the polymers on an iron oxide red pigment, the dispersion stability, as well as the adhesion of the polymer coatings on steel plates and their corrosion protection.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of Q, e parameters for methyl α‐cyanoacrylate
The copolymerization of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine<sup>1</sup>
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The bulk copolymerization reactions of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine(MVP) with styrene(St), methyl methacrylate(MMA), methyl acrylate(MA), and acrylonitrile(AN) at 60°C. have been investigated. The copolymer compositions were estimated by means of electrometric titrations in a nonaqueous solvent mixture.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios of the following systems were determined: St/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.812 ± 0.005; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.91 ± 0.02), MMA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.02; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.61 ± 0.08), MA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.172 ± 0.007; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.10), and AN/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.116 ± 0.003; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.27 ± 0.04). Moreover the Q‐ and e‐values were calculated for the methyl vinylpyridine and its behavior in copolymerization is discussed.</jats:p>

Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of triallyl eyanurate, triallyl isocyanurate, and diallylmelamine with methyl methacrylate, styrene, and vinyl acetate have been determined. Integral composition distribution curves have been determined for the triallyl cyanurate‐methyl‐methacrylate system.</jats:p>

Title: Synthèse par voie radicalaire de polymères à extrémités hydroxylées, 11. Etude de la copolymérisation du méthacrylate de méthyle avec divers acrylates et méthacrylates. Détermination des rapports de réactivité
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methylmethacrylate (MMA) was polymerized in an oxygen or argon atmosphere with butyl or isobutyl acrylates, and butyl, isobutyl, or 2,3‐epoxypropyl methacrylates, by hydrogen peroxyde in the presence of ethanol under UV irradiation (254 nm) at room temperature. The reactivity ratios were determined. MMA shows a higher reactivity than its comonomers, in good agreement with the results of the literature, except for isobutyl and 2,3‐epoxypropyl methacry‐lates.</jats:p>

Title: Microstructure of the copolymers of methyl methacrylate with other methacrylates obtained by radical and anionic copolymerizations in tetrahydrofuran
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were determined in the copolymerizations of methyl methacrylate (MMA, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with 1, 1‐diphenylethyl (DPEMA), α,α‐dimethylbenzyl (DMBMA), <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BuMA), diphenylmethyl (DPMMA), phenyl (PhMA), and 1‐naphthyl (NpMA) methacrylates (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) by azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) at 60°C and butyllithium (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BuLi) at −78°C. The reactivities of the monomers were explained in terms of the polar effect of the ester groups in both copolymerizations. All the copolymers isolated in low yields were converted to PMMA either directly or by copoly(MMA—methacrylic acid) to determine the triad tacticities of the copolymers. Coisotactic parameters σ<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and σ<jats:sub>21</jats:sub> were determined by assuming the terminal model statistics. The σ<jats:sub>21</jats:sub> values always accorded to the σ<jats:sub>21</jats:sub> values within experimental error, and in radical copolymerizations they were between isotactic parameters σ<jats:sub>11</jats:sub> and σ<jats:sub>22</jats:sub> of the homopolymerizations of MMA and <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> monomers. In anionic copolymerizations, however, the σ<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = σ<jats:sub>21</jats:sub> values varied, depending on the <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> monomers. In copolymerization with DPEMA the values were less than both σ<jats:sub>11</jats:sub> and σ<jats:sub>22</jats:sub> with DMBMA they were between σ<jats:sub>11</jats:sub> and σ<jats:sub>22</jats:sub>, with DPMMA, nearly equal to σ<jats:sub>11</jats:sub>, and with PhMA and NpMA, greater than both σ<jats:sub>11</jats:sub> and σ<jats:sub>22</jats:sub>. The application of these parameters to copolymerizations performed at high conversion was also investigated.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: The Emulsion Polymerization of Vinyl Bromide
Studies in copolymerization. The systems methyl methacrylate +p-methoxystyrene and styrene +m-vinyl phenol
Copolymérisation radicalaire du méthyl‐4 styrène avec le méthacrylate de méthyle ou l'acrylonitrile. Détermination des rapports de réactivité
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>4‐Methylstyrene (S) was copolymerized with methyl methacrylate (M) or acrylonitrile (A) in benzene or <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide solution, respectively. The reactions were carried out at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile as free‐radical initiator. The copolymer compositions were determined from oxygen (SM) or nitrogen (SA) analysis, 100 MHz <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR, and 25 MHz <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectra. These methods lead to the same results. Data plotted according to the Kelen‐Tüdős (K‐T) procedure indicate that the copolymerization of S with M can be adequately described by the terminal‐unit model. The corresponding reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,46 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>M</jats:sub> = 0,35 ± 0,02) were in good agreement with literature values and conform with the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>‐scheme. On the other hand, the K‐T plot for copolymerization of the SA system indicates deviations from the terminal model (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,27 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,01) in the S‐ and A‐rich regions. This departure was interpreted in terms of penultimate effects on the reactivity of the S‐ and A‐ended radicals. The values of the corresponding reactivity ratios were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SS</jats:sub> = 0,18 ± 0,03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AS</jats:sub> = 0,34 ± 0,04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AA</jats:sub> = 0,06 ± 0,01, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SA</jats:sub> = 0,13 ± 0,01. The theoretical curve of copolymer composition versus monomer feed, calculated with these parameters, is in excellent agreement with the experimental data. This finding shows that, on the basis of the composition data alone, the penultimate model provides an appropriate description of the copolymerization of S and A.</jats:p>

Title: Studies of the polymerization and copolymerization of methacrylic anhydride
Reactivity of vinyl ketones in free radical copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity of some monomer vinyl ketones in the radical copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate was studied on the basis of the Taft equation. It was concluded that the relative reactivities of the vinyl ketones in radical reactions increase with increasing electron‐withdrawing nature of the vinyl ketone substituent. Polar and steric effects do not affect the reactivity.</jats:p>

Title: La polymérisation et la copolymérisation du vinylmésitylène
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>La polymérisation du vinylmésitylène, ou 2‐4‐6‐triméthylstyrène, ne suit pas la loi usuelle de la racine carrée de la concentration en initiateur. Ce comportement particulier résulte de la formation de radicaux relativement stabilisés, auxquels les molécules de monomère peu réactionnel ne peuvent s'additionner ultérieurement. La vitesse de disparition du monomère est proportionnelle à la vitesse de décomposition du peroxyde de benzoyle.</jats:p><jats:p>Les copolymérisations du vinylmésitylène avec l'acrylonitrile, le méthacrylate de méthyle et le parachlorostyrène ont été également étudiées. Les paramètres<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>et<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>correspondants à ces copolymérisations ont été déterminés. Au cours de ces réactions, les vitesses de copolymérisation sont proportionnelles à la racine carrée de la concentration en initiateur; par contre, les degrés de polymérisation sont très peu élevés, et résultent de l'importance considérable des réactions de transfert de chaîne sur le vinylmésitylène. Le rapport des constantes de vitesse du transfert de chaîne et d'addition du vinylmésitylène ont pu être déterminées graphiquement dans les systèmes vinylmésitylène‐p.chlorostyrène et vinylmésitylène‐acrylonitrile; ces valeurs sont du même ordre de grandeur que celles obtenues précédemment pour l'α‐méthylstyrène. Ces résultats expérimentaux ont été interprétés; ils résultent de la réactivité restreinte du vinylmésitylène. Par analyse spectrométrique infrarouge, on peu mettre en évidence un empêchement stérique considérable à l'endroit de la double soudure vinylique; de plus, à partir des paramètres<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>et r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, on trouve une valeur de la réactivité du vinylmésitylène égale à 0,2‐0,25 environ, si on attribue une valeur unitaire au styrène, suivant l'équation d'Alfrey‐Price.</jats:p><jats:p>La stabilisation relative des radicaux, issus du monomère, résulte d'une structure benzylique; une certaine stabilisation supplémentaire, due à une énergie de conjugaison partielle, est également probable.</jats:p>

Substituent effects in free radical copolymerization of substituted styrenes with acrylates and methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Relative reactivity ratios have been determined for <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene with five lower acrylates and methacrylates, respectively, and for methyl acrylate with a number of substituted styrenes in free‐radical copolymerization. Analysis of the data shows that: (a) acrylates are less reactive than methacrylates with <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene; (b) length of the side chain has little or no effect in methacrylates, but its effect is pronounced in acrylates with respect to their reactivity ratios; (c) chlorine substitution in the side chain of either acrylates or methacrylates has a significant influence on the reactivity ratio; (d) relative reactivity ratio data for methyl acrylate with substituted styrenes fail to show the expected relationship between monomer structure and resonance theory, inductive effect and, consequently, the Hammett σ values.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: 1H‐NMR study of structure and tacticity in p‐t‐butylstyrene/methyl methacrylate copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers prepared by the bulk copolymerization of <jats:italic>p‐t</jats:italic>‐butylstyrene (S) and methyl methacrylate (M) were analyzed by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR. The spectra showed fine structure in the δ 2.2–3.6 region similar to that reported for styrene/methyl methacrylate copolymers. Reactivity ratios for S‐M copolymers determined by classical composition measurements differed markedly from the same ratios determined by NMR when it was assumed that NMR peak‐triad assignments could be made by analogy with published styrene/methyl methacrylate assignments. A new set of peak‐triad assignments was proposed that reconciles this difficulty and gives good agreement between triad fractions measured by NMR and those calculated from theory.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free‐radical copolymerization of methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate with 9‐vinylanthracene was studied, and the reactivity ratios <jats:bold><jats:italic>r</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were calculated. In the light of earlier data on copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene with styrene results show that the difference in polarity of the monomers participating in the copolymerization has an insignificant influence compared with that of the steric factors involved in the reaction.</jats:p>
