Copolymérisation radicalaire de méthacrylates de 2-aminoéthyle avec le méthacrylate de méthyle
Determination of propagation and termination rate constants for some methacrylates in their radical polymerizations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Rotating sector determinations of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> for ten methacrylates undergoing radical polymerization were carried out at 30°C. Ester groups in the monomers were: isopropyl, ethyl, β‐cyclohexylethyl, methyl, γ‐phenylpropyl, β‐phenylethyl, β‐methoxyethyl, benzyl, β‐chloroethyl, and phenyl. Values of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> obtained were 121, 126, 1190, 141, 149, 228, 249, 1250, 254, and 411 l./mole‐sec., respectively; values of 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> × 10<jats:sup>−6</jats:sup> were 4.52, 7.35, 32.8, 11.6, 0.813, 1.88, 9.30, 41.9, 6.71, and 11.9 l./mole‐sec., respectively.</jats:p><jats:p>Omitting the data for the β‐cyclohexylethyl and benzyl esters, a Taft correlation, log <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = (0.70 ± 0.18)σ* + 2.2, was established, where σ* denotes Taft's polar substitutent constants for the above‐mentioned ester groups. The steric substituent constants <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>s</jats:italic></jats:sub> were found to have no influence on <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>. Combination of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> data from copolymerization studies with styrene or methyl methacrylate as M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> comonomer revealed that the more reactive monomer gave rise to the more reactive polymer radical. Monomer viscosities and molar volumes of the ester groups were found to correlate with 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Free‐radical homopolymerization and copolymerization of ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate in tetrahydrofuran
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate (EHMA) was polymerized in a 3 mol/L tetrahydrofuran solution at 50°C, using 2–2' azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The kinetic behavior indicates a higher polymerization rate for EHMA than for methyl methacrylate (MMA). Copolymerization reaction between MMA and EHMA, under the same experimental conditions, was carried out and values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 1.264 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>EHMA</jats:sub> = 1.285 were found for the reactivity ratios. The comparison of triad sequences as determined from Bernouillian statistic to those calculated from the experimental spliting of <jats:italic>O</jats:italic>‐methyl and α‐methyl <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR signals of the copolymers confirm the obtained results. © 1992 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Determination of halogen in copolymers by dye‐partition technique and calculation of r1 therefrom
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Halogen‐bearing polymers have been prepared by copolymerization of monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) such as styrene, methyl methacrylate, methyl acrylate, and vinyl acetate with traces of chlorine‐bearing monomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) such as allyl chloride and tetrachloroethylene at varying M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>:M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ratios in the 100:1 composition range. The halogen atoms in the copolymers were transformed to quaternary pyridinium halide groups by quaternization with pyridine. The copolymer compositions and the monomer reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> were determined by the estimation of the quaternary halide groups in the copolymers by the dye‐partition technique, with aqueous disulfine blue VN150 in 0.01<jats:italic>M</jats:italic> hydrochloric acid as the dye reagent.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Butadiene/styrene/2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine terpolymer. Composition–conversion data in comparison with calculated values
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Terpolymers from 1,3‐butadiene, styrene, and vinylpyridine are important as rubbers, and, in latex form, as components of rubber‐to‐fabric adhesives. Three monomer mixtures having the approximate weight composition butadiene/styrene/2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine 70/15/15, 25/48/27, and 38.5/49/12.5 have been emulsion‐polymerized at 30°C., and the terpolymer composition as a function of the conversion has been studied. The six monomer reactivity ratios have been determined by binary copolymerizations at 30°C. and checked by low conversion bulk terpolymerizations. Average and instantaneous composition–conversion curves have been calculated, on the assumption of a constant reaction volume, by numerical integration of the terpolymerization equations on electronic computer. Details, of general applicability, for calculations are given. The experimental results of the emulsion terpolymerizations fit satisfactorily the calculated curves over a wide range of conversions.</jats:p>

Title: Photo and thermal polymerizations sensitized by donor–acceptor interaction. II. Photopolymerization and electronic spectroscopy of the isobutyl vinyl ether–acrylonitrile system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Photopolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN), an acceptor monomer, was found to be accelerated in the presence of isobutyl vinyl ether (IBVE), a donor monomer. The propagation is completed by a radical mechanism as judged by copolymer compositions; in contrast to the <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylcarbazole–AN system studied previously. This photopolymerization system is entirely stable if kept in the dark. The comparison of the relation between <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and [IBVE]/[AN] ratio in the monomer feed found for the spontaneous photopolymerization with that for radical polymerization initiated by azobisisobutylonitrile in the dark leads to the conclusion that the rate of photoinitiation is enhanced by the interaction between AN and IBVE, whereas the propagation step by a radical mechanism is retarded by increasing concentration of IBVE. The contact charge‐transfer complex between IBVE and AN was confirmed by electronic spectroscopy of the polymerization system, which showed photosensitization by charge‐transfer interaction. The spectroscopic study of other weak donor–weak acceptor systems is also discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: The Effect of Zinc Chloride on the Copolymerization of Some Allylic Compounds with Acrylonitrile

Title: Copolymerization characteristics of ethyl vinyl ether and its beta‐bromo and beta‐carbethoxy derivatives
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of ethyl vinyl ether with acrylonitrile leads to values of the copolymerization parameters of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.06 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.8. Calculations from other data in the literature suggested that <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.015 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −1.6 are better values. Copolymerization of β‐bromovinyl ethyl ether with styrene and methyl methacrylate indicates <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.014 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.35. For ethyl β‐ethoxyacrylate, copolymerization with styrene and acrylonitrile indicates <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.015 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.3. Both substituted vinyl lethers showed a much lower reactivity (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> factor) than expected. The decreased resonance interaction in these molecules was further supported by infrared data. Attempts to prepare β‐chlorovinyl methyl ether by three different methods were unsuccessful.</jats:p>

Title: Studies in cyclocopolymerization. Relative rates of addition in the free radical‐initiated copolymerization of 1,4‐dienes and substituted olefins
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A general copolymer composition equation is developed for the cyclocopolymerization of 1,4‐dienes (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and monoolefins (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>). The general equation relates copolymer composition to monomer feed composition in terms of five reactivity ratio parameters. When cyclization is very rapid relative to other chain propagation steps the general equation simplifies to the form: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = (1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)(1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)/[<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic> + (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>) + 2], where <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = [m<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[m<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the copolymer, <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> = [M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>][M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the monomer feed, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> are reactivity ratios for the chain propagation steps of diene, monoolefin, and cyclized radicals, respectively. The theory is applied to the free radical initiated copolymerization of (A) divinyl ether/maleic anhydride, (B) 1,4‐pentadiene/maleic anhydride, (C) divinyl ether/<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide, (D), divinyl ether/acrylonitrile; and (E) 1,4‐pentadiene/acrylonitrile. Systems A, B, and C form alternating copolymers of composition <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 0.5. For system D, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.024, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.938, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> = 0.017. For system E, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ⋍ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> ⋍ O, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.13.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Copolymerization. V.<sup>1</sup> Some Copolymerizations of Vinyl Acetate

Title: Reactive fiber. Part I. Copolymerization and copolymer of acrylonitrile with glycidyl methacrylate and with glycidyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>As one of the ways to obtain high molecular compounds which have chemical reactivity, the copolymerizations of acrylonitrile with glycidyl methacrylate, and with glycidyl acrylate were examined to prepare the copolymers which are soluble, moldable and spinnable. The homogeneous reaction of the copolymers with amines in dimethylformamide and the heterogeneous reaction of the fibers from copolymers with amines, amino acids, and dyes containing amino, phenolic hydroxyl groups was carried out, and it was assumed that the copolymer of acrylonitrile with glycidyl methacrylate was a “Reactive Polymer” having considerable chemical reactivity.</jats:p>

Title: Polyaddition Reactions of Bisepoxy Compounds
COMPOSITIONAL HETEROGENEITY OF BUTADIENE–ACRYLONITRILE COPOLYMERS PREPARED IN EMULSION AT 5°C
Abstract: <jats:p> The copolymerization of butadiene and acrylonitrile is very similar to the copolymerization of butadiene and styrene. Polymers predominantly butadiene may be studied by conventional solution techniques but the study of polymers rich in acrylonitrile requires improved solvents for these materials. Polymerization rates are greatest for monomer ratios approximating equal proportions. The mercaptan modifier disappears much more slowly than in the butadiene–styrene system, the regulating index approximating unity. The number average molecular weights calculated from the mercaptan disappearance curves indicate uniform polymer molecular weights to relatively high conversions after which there is a decrease. The viscosity data indicate a rise in viscosity with conversion, which effect is overcome for charges rich in acrylonitrile by the lessening of branching, the more rapid disappearance of mercaptan at high conversion, and the tendency of polymers containing over 50% acrylonitrile to show very low dilute solution viscosities in the solvents tested. Viscosity molecular weights have been calculated and estimates of the molecular weight distribution made. These distributions appear to be quite narrow and the usual broadening at higher conversions is prevented by the increased modifier consumption and increased vinyl content of the polymer prepared with 50 parts acrylonitrile in the charge. The bound acrylonitrile has been determined at various conversions and the reactivity ratios have been found to be r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.28 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.02 for emulsions and r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.18 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03 for oil phase portion only. Q is 0.74 and e is 1.47 as calculated by the Alfrey–Price equations. </jats:p>

Title: The Polymerization of Butene Isomers
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The effect of the methyl substituents of four butene isomers (IB, NB, TB and CB) on their polymerizations and copolymerizations has been investigated. None of these monomers homopolymerized in the presence of an ordinary radical or in that of anionic catalysts, but they were homopolymerized by cationic catalysts. The reactivity of these monomers toward their cationic polymerizations and radical copolymerizations has been found to decrease in the order of IB&gt;&gt;NB&gt;TB–CB. These results have been interpreted on the basis of the steric effect and the chain transfer reactivity of the methyl substituents in these monomers.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>These monomers, except for IB, can easily be homopolymerized by the Natta catalyst in the reactivity order of NB&gt;&gt;TB&gt;–CB. The resulting polymers from TB and CB have been confirmed to be the same as the polymer from NB, which consisted of the recurring unit of n-butene-1.</jats:p>
Journal: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan

Title: Radical Terpolymerization of 2-Chloroethyl Vinyl Ether, Maleic Anhydride and Acrylonitrile

Title: Über die copolymerisation des acroleins und des methacroleins in homogener lösung. Polymere acroleine. 25. Mitt.
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Copolymerisation des Acroleins und des Methacroleins in Dimethylformamid sowie in Dioxan wird beschrieben. Die Parameter folgender Systeme wurden bestimmt: Acrolein/Acrylnitril (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,60; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,52); Acrolein/Acrylamid (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,69; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,21); Acrolein/Methacrylnitril (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,72; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1,20); Acrolein/2‐Vinylpyridin (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0) und Methacrolein/Methacrylnitril (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,78; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,40). Die Berechnung der Q‐und e‐Werte bzw. der q‐ und ϵ‐Werte ergab für Acrolein: Q = 0,64; e = 0,61; q = ‐2,8 kcal/Mol; ϵ = 0,19 = 10<jats:sup>−10</jats:sup> elektrostatische Einheiten und für Methacrolein: Q = 1,59; e = 0,36; q = −3,4 kcal/Mol; ϵ = 0,11 = 10<jats:sup>−10</jats:sup> elektrostatische Einheiten.</jats:p>

Title: Das copolymerisationsverhalten des atropasäuremethylesters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Copolymerisation des Atropasäuremethylesters mit Styrol, Acrylnitril, Methylacrylat und Methylmethacrylat (MMA) wurde bei 60°C untersucht. Dabei zeigte sich, daß im gebildeten Polymerenmolekül höchstens zwei Methylatropatrundbausteine unmittel bar aufeinander folgen können, und die Resultate werden durch eine Gleichung, die diese Eigenheit berücksichtigt, besser beschrieben als durch die übliche Copolymerisationsgleichung. Bei der Copolymerisation mit dem sperrigen MMA können überhaupt keine Atropaestersequenzen mehr gebildet werden (r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0). Aus den Parametern der Comonomeren (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) wird Q<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5,0 und e<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = +0,8 erhalten.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization parameters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization parameters, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>, have been calculated for several monomers whose relative reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic>, are available. The ratios and parameters are tabulated in an effort to bring the various data in the literature to a single source of reference.</jats:p>

Title: Mischpolymerisation des Acrylnitrils mit Butylacrylat die Bestimmung der Mischpolymerisationsparameter und der Q- und e-Werte für Butylacrylat
Copolymerization of Acrylonitrile and ω-Substituted 1-Olefins -Increased Reactivity of Olefin Monomers with the Pendant Aromatic Group
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Zum copolymerisationsverhalten extrem sperriger α‐substituierter styrole
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Copolymerisation von Methacrylnitril mit Atropasäuremethylester, α‐Methoxystyrol und Diphenyläthylen wurde untersucht. Unter der Annahme, daß der vorletzte Grundbaustein die Reaktivität der wachsenden Polymerkette beeinflussen kann und daß nie mehr als zwei α‐substituierte Styrolgrundbausteine unmittelbar aufeinander folgen können, wurde eine allgemeingültige Gleichung für Copolymerisationen mit solchen extrem sperrigen Monomeren abgeleitet. Die drei in dieser Gleichung auftretenden Copolymerisationsparameter lassen sich durch die Q‐ und ϵ‐Werte der Monomeren und zusätzliche „sterische Parameter”︁ ausdrücken. Diese sterischen Parameter stellen anschauliche Kennzahlen für die auftretenden sterischen Hinderungen dar.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. XV.<sup>1</sup> Copolymerization of Acetylene Derivatives with Olefins. Retardation by Radicals from Acetylenes
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Thermal copolymerizations of vinyl sulfides with some weak acceptor monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Thermal copolymerizations of vinyl sulfides (VS) with some weak electron‐accepting monomers were studied on the basis of donor‐acceptor interaction. VS were thermally polymerized in the presence of diethyl fumarate, dimethyl maleate, acrylonitrile (AN) methyl methacrylate (MMA), methyl acrylate, and ethyl acrylate (EA) in the absence of radical initiators to yield copolymers. The monomer/copolymer composition curves for these copolymerizations were quite similar to those produced from polymerizations initiated by α.α′‐azobisisobutyronitrile, indicating that the propagating species are free radicals. Similar conclusions were obtained from experiments with the inhibitor benzoquinone, and from the small observed solvent effect, but no proof for the occurrence of cationic or anionic polymerization was obtained.</jats:p><jats:p>Although the existence of a 1 : 1 donor/acceptor complex in AN/VS system was spectroscopically confirmed, such interaction was appreciably weak, in comparison to that of maleic anhydride/VS. In the systems MMA/VS and EA/VS no interaction was observed. Accordingly, the intiating radical species in AN/VS system might be considered to be formed through donor/acceptor interaction. It was also found that alternative copolymers were obtained from thermal copolymerization of AN with VS in the presence of zinc chloride. The initiation mechanism for these thermal copolymerization is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. VII. Relative rates of addition of various monomers in copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Information concerning monomer reactivity in copolymerization has been obtained for thirteen copolymerization systems. The influence of substituents and chain length in vinyl polymerization is discussed in the light of this and preceding data. Unsaturated acid behavior in copolymerizations is discussed for the first time.</jats:p>

Title: The Emulsion Copolymerization of N-Methylolacrylamide
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

p‐Vinylbenzoic acid: A convenient preparation, copolymerization, and examination as dye receptive modifier for acrylic fibers and as ion exchange resin component
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A convenient preparation of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylbenzoic acid from β‐haloethylbenzene with 67% overall yield was described. Monomer reactivity ratio of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylbenzoic acid (1) to acrylonitrile (2) was determined:
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula></jats:p><jats:p><jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Vinylbenzoic acid increased the affinity of acrylic fibre toward cationic dye when copolymerized with acrylonitrile, but was less effective than sulfonic acids as dye receptive site. Acid ion exchange resins based on <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylbenzoic acid possessed a high selection factor of Ca<jats:sup>2+</jats:sup> over Mg<jats:sup>2+</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Temperature dependence of copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization rate constant ratios have been determined as a function of temperature for the monomer pairs: styrene‐acrylonitrile and dichlorostyrene‐acrylonitrile. The temperature dependence, which represents the difference of the activation energies of the respective addition reactions, is of the magnitude expected, except for the styrene‐dichlorostyrene system.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with N‐substituted maleimides
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylonitrile was copolymerized with three N‐arylmaleimides as well as with N‐octadecylmaleimide in dimethylformamide (DMF) using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by the Fineman‐Ross and the Kelen‐Tüdős methods from which the Q‐ and e‐parameters of these monomers were evaluated. The prepared copolymers were characterized by viscosity measurements and thermal analysis. The intrinsic viscosity decreases by increasing the maleimide content in the copolymer. Thermogravimetry TG and differential thermal analysis (DTA) data showed a remarkable improvement in the thermal behaviour of the investigated copolymers. A mechanism for the participation of the maleimide units in the nitrile oligomerization was also proposed. The investigation of the dyeing properties of the copolymers with the exception of those containing octadecylmaleimide, showed good affinity towards basic dyes as well as an appreciable improvement in their colour fastness towards UV light.</jats:p>

Title: Photo and thermal polymerization sensitized by donor–acceptor interaction. I. N‐vinyl‐carbazole–acrylonitrile and related systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Spontaneous photo and thermal polymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylcarbazole (VCZ)–acrylonitrile (AN), VCZ–acetonitrile, AN‐N‐ethylcarbazole, and AN‐ferrocene were studied. These combinations of electron donor with acceptor were thermally rather stable but showed prominent photopolymerizability when the systems were irradiated by near ultraviolet light. The VCZ–AN system showed multireactivity producing VCZ polymer and a copolymer of VCZ with AN. The composition of copolymer was approximately the same as that of polymer produced in radical copolymerization. The effects of additives (DPPH, NH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O, air) indicated simultaneous occurrence of cationic and radical polymerization in the AN–VCZ and acetonitrile–VCZ systems. The results were interpreted on the assumption of initial formation of a cation radical–anion radical pair. The ratio of cationic to radical polymerization differed for photo and thermal polymerization. In no case was anionic polymerization detected.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Reactivity ratios of some monomer pairs
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To continue the study of the effect of structure on reactivity, an experimental investigation of the free radical copolymerization behavior of eight monomer pairs has been made. The monomer pairs include: vinyl acetate‐methyl vinyl ketone; vinyl acetate‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; acrylonitrile‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; methylacrolein‐acrylonitrile; vinylsulfonic acid‐methyl methacrylate; 2,5‐dichlorostyrene‐2,5‐dimethylstyrene; vinyl acetate‐fumaryl chloride; and styrene‐fumaryl chloride.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with benzyl- and tetrahydrofuryl acrylates
Measurement of copolymerization reactivity ratios by NMR
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part B: Polymer Letters

Title: Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile–phenyl acrylate copolymerization systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for various acrylonitrile–phenyl acrylate systems have been determined for radical copolymerization at 60°C in dimethylformamide. The values of the ratios calculated by the linear graphical method of Kelen and Tüdös were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.36 ± 0.04 for acrylonitrile–phenyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.73 ± 0.02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.80 ± 0.02 for acrylonitrile–<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐cresyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33 ± 0.03 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.9 ± 0.02 for acrylonitrile–<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.82 ± 0.03 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.02 ± 0.03 for acrylonitrile–<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐bromophenyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12 ± 0.05 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.16 ± 0.05 for acrylonitryle–<jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl acrylate, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.26 ± 0.05 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.86 ± 0.05 for acrylonitrile–<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl acrylate. The dependence of reactivities of the monomers upon their chemical structure was discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Polymérisation radicalaire du pentadiène‐1,3. I. Copolymérisation des cis et trans pentadiènes‐1,3 avec l'acrylonitrile. Détermination des rapports de réactivité
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>Cis</jats:italic> (CP) and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> (TP) isomers of 1,3‐pentadiene (piperylene) were homo and copolymerized with acrylonitrile (A) in bulk and emulsion, at 50°C, using azobisisobutyronitrile and potassium persulfate as free radical initiators. The <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic> isomer reacts more rapidly than the <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> monomer. The copolymer compositions were determined from nitrogen analysis, 100‐MH<jats:sub>z</jats:sub> <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR and 25‐MHz <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra. The results thus obtained show that both the bulk and emulsion processes yield copolymers characterized by a very similar composition. Data plotted according to the Kelen‐Tüdös method indicate that the terminal‐unit model is applicable to the piperylene‐acrylonitrile system. Reactivity ratios for bulk copolymerization were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.079, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>TP</jats:sub> = 0.114, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.033, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>CP</jats:sub> = 0.188. These values are very small and hence suggest a strong alternating tendency for acrylonitrile and 1,3‐pentadiene in both comonomer systems. This latter conclusion is corroborated by the comparison of the NMR spectra of the synthesized copolymers with that of a standard alternating sample. The reactivity (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>) and electronegativity (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) of the 1,3‐pentadiene isomers calculated from the reactivity ratios by the Alfrey—Price equations were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>TP</jats:sub> = 0.56, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>TP</jats:sub> = −0.97 and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>CP</jats:sub> = 1.215, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>CP</jats:sub> = −1.055 for <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic> dienes, respectively.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Acroleindiethylacetal: Reaction with free radicals and copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reaction between acroleindiethylacetal (3.3‐diethoxypropene) and free radicals and the behaviour of this acetal in the free radical copolymerization with unsaturated monomers has been investigated. The decomposition of benzoyl peroxide and tert.‐butyl peroxide in acroleindiethylacetal has been studied in the liquid phase. On the basis of the obtained products a mechanism is proposed which involves the abstraction of a hydrogen atom by a primary radical from a carbon atom which is adjacent to oxygen. We also tried to copolymerize the acetal with several conventional comonomers but copolymers were only obtained when acrylonitrile and maleic anhydride were used. The remarkably uniform composition of the copolymers from the acetal and maleic anhydride is explained through a donor‐acceptor complex between the two monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters for copolymers incorporating n‐octadecyl acrylate and N‐n‐octadecylacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters were determined for <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octadecyl acrylate and <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide with several monomers not previously reported. Values of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> for the long‐chain acrylate now agreed more closely than before with the average of values for the lower acrylate homologs. The average polarity parameter for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide still showed more electron withdrawal from the double bond (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.42) than was expressed by the average literature value (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.10) for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octylacrylamide. Because penultimate effects were absent in this work, the reason for the discrepancy seems to reside in the copolymer analysis. Reactivity ratios for oleyl and octadecyl acrylate with methyl methacrylate were similar. Coefficients for the relation between overall rates of copolymerization and composition were obtained on some systems by curve fitting with a computer. They generally showed a slight minimum.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Reactivity ratios of vinyl esters of aliphatic acids and some common vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization reaction of five vinyl esters of aliphatic acids with vinyl chloride, vinylidene chloride, acrylonitrile, butadiene, styrene, and methyl acrylate have been studied. The reactivity ratios have been determined and the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for the esters have been calculated. The results clearly show that the nature of the acyl residue in a vinyl ester has little influence on its reactivity ratio in a copolymerization reaction or on the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> value.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of 1-vinyl naphthalene with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and acrylonitrile
Copolymerization of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione with acrylonitrile and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile and methyl methacrylate with 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is reported. The copolymers were prepared by heating the monomer feeds in sealed tubes with α,α′‐azobisisobutyronitrile. Infrared bands for both the β‐diketone and the nitrile, in the case of acrylonitrile, or ester, in the case of methyl methacrylate, indicated that copolymerization had occurred. The acrylonitrile copolymers were insoluble in the common solvents and swelled on treatment with dimethylformamide and dimethylsulfoxide. The methyl methacrylate copolymers were partially soluble in the usual solvents with the solubility and gel content varying with the composition of the copolymers. Solution viscosities indicated high molecular weights. The reduced specific viscosity of the sodium salt of the 0.05 methyl methacrylate copolymer increased with decreasing concentration, a characteristic typical of polyelectrolytes. The compositions of the copolymers were determined from the nitrogen analyses for acrylonitrile copolymers, and the ultraviolet absorption of the β‐diketone for the methyl methacrylate copolymers. The molar extinction coefficient of the β‐diketone structural unit was estimated from a study of model compounds. The reactivity ratios were evaluated by the usual methods. For the acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.67, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.21. For the methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.4, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.083. For each system <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione were evaluated. The average values are <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.20, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.42. The behavior of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione is compared with maleic anhydride and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐butylmaleimide with respect to the reactivity of the monomer, the reactivity of the radical, and the effective polarity of the double bond.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Copolymerization Reactivities of α-Substituted Crotonyl Monomers
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile. I. Copolymerization with styrene derivatives containing nitrile groups in the side chain
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylonitrile was copolymerized in bulk with cinnamonitrile (I), ethyl benzylidenecyanoacetate (II), and benzylidenemalononitrile (III) by radical initiation up to low conversions. The conventional scheme of copolymerization fitted all the three copolymer pairs.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Copolymerization Parameters of Itaconic Anhydride in Free-Radical Polymerization

The Preparation of Vinyl Isocyanate and its Copolymerization Reactions
Copolymerization Characteristics of Two Vinylsilanes
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Copolymerization kinetics for 2‐isopropenyl‐2‐oxazoline (methods and results)
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios for 2‐isopropenyl‐2‐oxazoline (IPO), a dual functional monomer, have been determined using a combination of gas chromatography, with an internal standard, and a new form of the integrated copolymerization equation. The results indicate a parallel trend with the reactivity ratios of styrene in spite of the large disparity in polarity between IPO and styrene.</jats:p>

Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 9. Copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate (2‐NM) with acrylonitrile (AN) initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was carried out in solvents with different dielectric constants. The relative reactivity ratios of the monomers determined by the Fineman‐Ross method in the solvents used are as follows:
<jats:list list-type="simple">
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in chloroform: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,96 ± 0,05; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in benzene: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,84 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,01 ± 0,04</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetone: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,52 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetonitrile: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,51 ± 0,06; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,03</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list></jats:p><jats:p>The capability of the monomers to form donor‐acceptor associates was shown by means of <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The observed interactions between the monomer molecules on one side and between the molecules of the monomers and the solvent on the other side were used to explain the changes in the reactivity ratios of both monomers obtained in different solvents.</jats:p>

Title: Radical polymerization of butadiene‐1‐carboxylic acid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The homopolymerization and copolymerization of butadiene‐1‐carboxylic acid (Bu‐1‐Acid) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were studied in tetrahydrofuran at 50°C with azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator. The initial rate of polymerization was proportional to [AIBN]<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> and [Bu‐1‐Acid]<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>. The overall activation energy for the polymerization was 22.87 kcal/mole. For copolymerization with styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) and acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), the monomer reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were determined by the Fineman‐Ross method, as follows; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 5.55, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.08 (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = styrene); <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 11.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03 (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = acrylonitrile). Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> values calculated from these values were 6.0 and +0.11, respectively. The Bu‐1‐Acid unit in the copolymer as well as the homopolymer was found from infrared and NMR spectral analyses to be composed of a <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,4 bond. The hydrogen‐transfer polymerization of Bu‐1‐Acid leading to polyester was attempted with triphenylphosphine as initiator, but did not occur.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Polymerizations of nitroalkyl acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We have prepared some nitroalkyl acrylates and methacrylates by a method involving alcoholysis, and investigated their polymerizability. 2‐Nitrobutyl acrylate (NBA) was extensively studied. The especially purified NBA monomer has good polymerizability without inhibiting radical polymerization and gives a thermally stable polymer. From copolymerization experiments with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and acrylonitrile, the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of NBA were estimated to be 0.47 and 0.85, respectively. The copolymerization behavior of NBA with some polyglycol dimethacrylates and unsaturated polyesters are comparable to those of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate. This monomer has little tendency to polymerize with organometallic initiators, but some polymers obtained are found to be crystalline. The polar and steric effects of the nitro group situated on the ester side chain are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Silyl enol ethers as monomer. I. Radical copolymerizability of α‐trimethylsilyloxystyrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>α‐Trimethylsilyloxystyrene (TMSST), the silyl enol ether of acetophenone, was not homopolymerized either by a radical or a cationic initiator. Radical copolymerization of TMSST with styrene (ST) and acrylonitrile (AN) in bulk and the terpolymerization of TMSST, ST, and maleic anhydride (MA) in dioxane were studied at 60°C and the polymerization parameters of TMSST were estimated. The rate of copolymerization decreased with increased amounts of TMSST for both systems. Monomer reactivity ratios were found as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.48 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 for the ST (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–TMSST (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.050 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 for the AN (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–TMSST (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system. The terpolymerization of ST (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), TMSST (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), and MA (M<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) gave a terpolymer containing ca. 50 mol % of MA units with a varying ratio of TMSST to ST units and the ratio of rate constants of propagation, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>32</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub>, was found to be 0.39. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of TMSST were determined using the values shown above to be 0.88 and −1.13, respectively. Attempted desilylation by an acid catalyst for the copolymer of TMSST with ST afforded polystyrene partially substituted with hydroxyl groups at the α‐position.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Radical Copolymerization Behavior of Alkyl Vinyl Sulfides
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with some transition metal acrylates. I. Determination of monomer reactivity ratios in radical copolymerization of acrylonitrile with zinc acrylate in dimethylformamide
Radical copolymerization behavior of ethyl vinyl sulfoxide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerizations of ethyl vinyl sulfoxide (EVSO) with various vinyl monomers were investigated. The copolymerizations of EVSO with styrene, methyl methacrylate and acrylonitrile gave copolymers having minor amounts of EVSO. Vinyl chloride and vinyl acetate, however, did not give any homopolymer and copolymer. From the copolymerization with styrene, EVSO was evaluated as an electron‐accepting and non‐conjugative monomer: Q = 0.13 and e = 0.61.</jats:p><jats:p>The effects of LEWIS acids (LiCl, ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) and proton donors (phenols, alcohols) on the monomer reactivity of EVSO were also investigated. These additives were found to enhance the monomer reactivity of EVSO. From the spectroscopic studies, it was concluded that the rate enhancement in monomer reactivity was attributable to the formation of a complex or to a hydrogen bond formation between the EVSO monomer and these additives.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerizations of N‐vinyluccinmmide and of N,N‐methyl vinyl p‐toluenesulfonamide with some vinyl compounds
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylsuccinimide (VSI) and of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methyl vinyl <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐toluenesulfonamide (VSA) with vinyl acetate (VAc), acrylonitrile (AN), stryrene (St), methyl acrylate (MA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and n‐butyl vinyl ether (BVE) were examianed at 60°C., using benzoyl peroxide or azobisiobutyronitrile as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios and the monomer reactivity factors of VSI and VSA were as follows. VSI as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 15, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 (VBE); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.09, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 7.0 (St); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.05, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.185 (VAc); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.4. r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.2 (MA); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.54 (AAAN), Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.15, e<jats:sub>1M/s</jats:sub> = ‐0.26. VSA as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.42 (AN); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.68 (MMA) r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 12.3 (St); Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.092, e<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = ‐0.87. The difference in copolymeizability between VSI and VSA sesms to arise primarily from the difference in thieir polarity factors.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile and vinyl pyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 5‐ethyl‐2‐vinyl pyridine, 2‐vinyl pyridine, and 4‐vinyl pyridine has been investigated. The copolymer compositions have been determined by the titration of the copolymers in nonaqueous solvents with perchloric acid in glacial acetic acid, using methyl violet as an indicator. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, respectively, have been determined in the three systems: AN/5‐ethyl‐2‐VP, (0.02 ± 0.02 and 0.43 ± 0.05); AN/2‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.002 and 0.47 ± 0.03); and AN/4‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.005 and 0.41 ± 0.09). The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for individual monomers have been calculated and compared with each other. The data obtained present no evidence for different reactivities of 2‐ and 4‐VP. The data shows that 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP has reactivity similar to those of above two monomers, but some difference caused by its ethyl group has been found. It has been also shown that the reactivity of 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP is quite identical with that of styrene.</jats:p>

Title: Radical polymerization of 3,3-bis(ethoxycarbonyl)propyl vinyl ether via an addition-abstraction mechanism
Sulfur-Containing Vinyl Monomers. XV. Kinetic Study of Radical Polymerization of Vinyl Mercaptobenzothiazole and Its Copolymerization

Title: High Pressure Copolymerization of Vinyl Monomers with Crotonaldehyde

Title: Zur polymerisation und copolymerisation von α‐methoxystyrol
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>α‐Methyoxystyrol läßt sich weder anionisch oder kationisch noch radikalisch homopolymerisieren. Bei der kationischen Copolymerisation erweist sich dieses Monomere reaktionsfähiger als Vinyläther. Seine Unfähigkeit, dabei längere Sequenzen zu bilden, weist auf das Vorliegen einer tiefen Ceilingtemperatur hin.</jats:p><jats:p>Bei der radikalischen Copolymerisation mit Styrol, Acrylnitril, Methylacrylat und Methylmethacrylat (MMA) wird für das α‐Methoxystyrol stets ein Parameter r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 gefunden. Aus den Parametern der ersten drei Comonomeren läßt sich Q = 0,65 und e = −1,20 abschätzen. Der relativ niedere Q‐Wert und die sehr geringe Reaktivität gegenüber dem Poly‐MMA‐Radikal zeigen, daß erhebliche sterische Hinderungen bei Polymerisationen mit diesem Monomeren auftreten.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization Studies of Cyclopropenone Ketals
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Silyl enol ethers as monomer. III. Radical polymerization and copolymerizations of 2‐trimethylsilyloxy‐1,3‐butadiene and desilylation of the resulting polymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Trimethylsilyloxy‐1,3‐butadiene (TMSBD), the silyl enol ether of methyl vinyl ketone, was homopolymerized with a radical initiator to afford polymers with a molecular weight of ca. 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>. Radical copolymerizations of TMSBD with styrene (ST) and acrylonitrile (AN) in bulk or dioxane at 60°C gave the following monomer reactivity ratios: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.64 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.20 for the ST (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–TMSBD (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.036 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.065 for the AN (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–TMSBD (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) system. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of TMSBD determined from the reactivity ratios for the former copolymerization system were 2.34 and −1.31, respectively. The resulting polymer and copolymers were readily desilylated with hydrochloric acid or tetrabutylammonium fluoride as catalyst to yield analogous polymers having carbonyl groups in the polymer chains.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Radical polymerization of muconic acid and ethyl muconate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Muconic acid (Mu‐acid) was found to polymerize to <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,4‐poly(Mu‐acid) with the use of azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator. Similarly, a muconic acid derivative, ethyl muconate (EMu), was readily polymerized through a <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,4 addition mechanism by the use of a radical or anionic catalyst, but did not polymerize when a cationic catalyst such as boron trifluoride etherate was used. Moreover, the copolymerization of Mu‐acid and EMu with various comonomers such as styrene, acryronitrile, and 2‐vinylpyridine was carried out and <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> values of Mu‐acid and EMu are discussed. These substituted diene monomers always polymerized through <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐1,4 addition with all catalysts and any comonomers.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Cyclodimerizations and Copolymerizations of Vinyl Ketones with Vinyl Monomers

Title: Copolymerization of 1-vinyltetrazole with vinyl monomers
Copolymerization of 3,4-epoxyhexahydrobenzyl acrylate with vinyl monomers
The Preparation of Isopropenylisocyanate and its Copolymerization
Estimation of reactivity ratios of N‐methacryloloxyphthalimide copolymers by1H NMR
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methacryloyloxyphthalimide (NMP) with methyl acrylate (MA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and acrylonitrile (AN) was carried out in dimethylformamide using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator at 60°C. The estimation of the copolymer compositions were carried by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios for NMP‐MA, NMP‐MMA, and NMP‐AN systems were found to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.223, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.208, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.441, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.704, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.496 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.228, respectively, by Kelen–Tüdős method. Also, the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for NMP monomer was found to be <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.90 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.01, respectively.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of vinyltrimethyl(phenyl)silanes with acrylonitrile
Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile–vinyl chloroacetate copolymerization systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile—vinyl chloroacetate systems have been determined for radical copolymerization at 60°C in dimethylformamide. The values of the ratios calculated by the linear graphical method of Kelen and Tüdös were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4.05 ± 0.1 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.001 ± 0.001 for acrylonitrile (AN)—vinyl monochloroacetate (VCAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.0 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.05 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl dichloroacetate (VDAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.13 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.06 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl trichloroacetate (VTAc). The penultimate model of the copolymerization and the effect of the vinyl chloroacetate structure were discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Radical copolymerization of potassium methacrylate and acrylonitrile in the presence of 18‐crown‐6 ether in ethyl alcohol as solvent
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Organometallic polymers. XXIV. Radical‐initiated copolymerization of ferrocenylmethyl acrylate and methacrylate with acrylonitrile, maleic anhydride, and N‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ferrocenylmethyl acrylate (I) and ferrocenylmethyl methacrylate (II) have been readily copolymerized with maleic anhydride in benzene–ethyl acetate solutions. Similarly, II has been copolymerized with both acrylonitrile and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone in benzene solutions to give higher molecular weight copolymers in high yields. In all cases azobisisobutyronitrile has been the initiator. Based on <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values obtained, the metal carbonyl substituent acts as an electron‐withdrawing group. Over a wide range of comonomers (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone, styrene, vinyl acetate, methyl acrylate, acrylonitrile, and maleic anhydride) I and II exhibit <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> values lower than (and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values higher than) similar copolymerizations with methyl acrylate or methyl methacrylate. Further more, the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> values found for I (0.03–0.11) and II (0.08–0.18) are smaller than those for methyl acrylate (0.46) and methyl methacrylate (0.74). Thus, I and II are less reactive than expected, presumably due to steric effects.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Radical copolymerization of 3‐tri‐n‐butylstannylstyrene with several vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical homopolymerization and copolymerization of 3‐tri‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylstannylstyrene (3‐BTS) with styrene (ST), ethyl acrylate (EA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), vinyl acetate (VA), and acrylonitrile (AN) were carried out using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) at 60°C. It was found that the yield of conversion to poly(3‐BTS) increased with the molar ratio of initiator to monomer as well as with polymerization time. The conversion at equilibrium after 50 h was about 40%. The compositions of copolymer samples were determined from elemental analyses. Monomer reactivity ratio and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated. The copolymers of 3‐BTS‐MMA and 3‐BTS‐AN were found to be alternating. The copolymers of 3‐BTS with MMA, EA and AN were not soluble in any of a large number of organic solvents tested. The insolubility is believed to be due to formation of intermolecular coordination among the tributylstannyl moiety and the carbonyl or cyano groups of the polymer. These copolymers, however, were “soluble” in trihaloacetic acid, but this solubility was due to a cleavage of the trialkyltin moiety from the phenyl groups. The glass temperatures, <jats:italic>T<jats:sub>g</jats:sub></jats:italic>, and melting temperatures <jats:italic>T<jats:sub>m</jats:sub></jats:italic>, of the various polymers were also studied.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Polymerizability of 1,3-Disubstituted 1,3-Butadiene and Preparation of New Alternating Copolymer
Free‐radical homopolymerization and copolymerization of vinylferrocene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The benzene solution homopolymerization of vinylferrocene, initiated by azobisisobutyronitrile, gave a series of benzene‐soluble homopolymers. Thus, free‐radical copolymerization studies were performed with styrene, methyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, acrylonitrile, vinyl acetate, and isoprene in benzene. With the exception of vinyl acetate and isoprene, which did not give copolymers with vinylferrocene under these conditions, smooth production of copolymers occurred. The relative reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, were obtained for vinylferrocene–styrene copolymerizations by using the curve‐fitting method for the differential form of the copolymer equation, by the Fineman‐Ross technique, and by computer fitting of the integrated form of the copolymer equations applied to higher conversion copolymerizations. In styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerizations, the curve‐fitting and Fineman‐Ross methods both gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.08, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.50, while the integration method gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.097, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.91. Application of the integration method to methyl acrylate and methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) gave values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.82, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.63; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.52, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.22, respectively. The curve‐fitting method gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.15, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.16 for acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerizations. From styrene copolymerizations, vinylferrocene exhibited values of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.145 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.47.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Synthesis of poly[3-(4-vinylphenoxy)phthalide-co-acrylonitrile] and the selective transport properties of its membranes
Evaluation of the terpolymer composition equation
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The equations describing the relationships between polymer composition and feed composition in a three‐monomer polymerization have been experimentally verified at high monomer conversions for the first time. In this paper, a three‐component system involving vinyl acetate‐octyl fumarate‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl pyrrolidone was analyzed. The six reactivity ratios, or relative reaction rate constants, were either taken from previous literature or determined from two‐component systems. The differential terpolymerization equations could be integrated analytically in special cases, owing to the negligibility of some of the terms, but a more precise technique was to integrate numerically with a digital computer. Two feed compositions were polymerized to various levels of fumarate conversion covering the entire range. The extent of conversion was determined polarographically. Average terpolymer compositions, determined by elemental analysis, checked with values predicted by the mathematical model well within experimental error. The calculations also showed that the instantaneous terpolymer composition can vary considerably during a batch polymerization and give rise to a spectrum of polymer properties.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate by proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate have been determined in bulk at 60°C for conversions smaller than 1% using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The values (r<jats:sub>ma</jats:sub> = 6.3 ± 0.4; r<jats:sub>va</jats:sub> = 0.031 ± 0.006) thus obtained were compared with the values obtained by other workers using different analytical techniques. The present method appears to be extremely simple and accurate.</jats:p>

Title: Studies on the polymerization of methacrylic esters. Part III. Copolymerization of n‐butyl methacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with vinyl acetate and acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylmethacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate as comonomers have been studied and the reactivity ratios of the monomers in copolymers reactions computed.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical polymerization and copolymerization of bicyclo‐(2.2.1)‐hepta‐(2.5)‐diene (norbornadiene)
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A brief study of the homopolymerization of norbornadiene indicated that pre‐gel polymer is limited to product having reduced viscosities below 0.2 dl./g. Pre‐gel polymer of 17,000 molecular weight was isolated and characterized: pre‐gel polynorbornadiene is soluble in benzene or chloroform, softens at 220–240°C., is thermosetting and shows poor molding characteristics. A cast rod of polynorbornadiene was found to have a heat distortion temperature of 186°C. and a flexural strength of 13,300 psi. Copolymer reactivity ratios of norbornadiene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) determined with vinyl acetate were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.3 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.8; with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ≈ 0.01 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ≈ 85. Thermal behavior of several copolymers was determined.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Cyclocopolymerization of Diallyl Phthalate with Vinyl Acetate and Methyl Acrylate
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Methyl α‐cyanoacrylate. II. Copolymerization studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methyl alpha;‐‐cyanoacrylate with five reference monomers gave values <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = +2.1 and of log <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.65, with much scatter in the latter value. Alternating copolymers are formed by copolymerization with monomers of <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.8 or less. Bulk copolymerization with such monomers could not be accomplished, as a rapid noncatalyzed polymerization occurred upon mixing even at 0°C. Random copolymers with methyl methacrylate could be prepared in bulk; those with ca. 10% methyl methacrylate had physical properties similar to the homopolymer of methyl α‐‐cyanoacrylate, except that the heat distortion temperature was lowered 10–15°C. The alternating copolymers were more thermally stable than the random copolymers. Glass temperature values for alternating copolymers do not appear to agree with values predicted from equations for random copolymers.</jats:p>

Some aspects of the copolymerization of vinylacetate and butylacrylate
Copolymerization. VII.<sup>1</sup> Copolymerizations of Some Further Monomer Pairs

Title: Free-Radical Copolymerizations of N-Phenyl Maleimide

Title: The free radical copolymerization of N-Vinyl carbazole
Allylic polymers. I. Copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate has been studied in the range from 10 to 90 mol % allyl esters in the feed. The Kelen‐Tüdos method was employed to determine the monomer reactivity ratios. The following values were found for the reactivity ratios: allyl propionate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.42, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.29; allyl butyrate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.64, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.97; allyl isobutyrate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.51, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.04; allyl valerate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.58, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.07; allyl trimethylacetate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.34, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.15. The <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> parameters were calculated from the allyl esters (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) reactivity ratios. The <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> parameters of allyl ester monomers have been found to be nicely correlated with parameters such as dissociation constants of carboxylic acids, which are constituents of allyl ester monomers, and Taft σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> constants of the alkyl group in the acids. The molecular weights of copolymers were measured by GPC and ranged from (1.0–15.0) × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Kinetik der radikalischen polymerisation und copolymerisation von N‐vinyl‐N‐methylacetamid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In order to get information on the kinetics of free radical polymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylacetamide (VIMA) polymerizations of the purified monomer were performed in dilatometers using the temperature range from 25 to 70°C, monomer concentrations of 10 to 100% in methanol, and initiation either by γY‐irradiation or by radical initiators. Molecular weight meassurements of the polymer were calibrated by light scattering determinations of <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub> according to the following equation at 30 °C in methanol: [η]/(ml/g) = 5,02 · 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> · <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub><jats:sup>0,794</jats:sup>6. Normal kinetics of free radical polymerization were found to be valid and Arrhenius parameters were calculated for the ratio <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> of the propagation rate constant <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and the termination rate constant <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> as well as for the monomer transfer constant <jats:italic>C</jats:italic><jats:sub>M</jats:sub> and for the efficiency of initiation <jats:italic>f</jats:italic>. For copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylacetamide with different comonomers the mean <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic>‐values were calculated as follows: <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>VIMA</jats:sub> ≅ 0,06; e<jats:sub>VIMA</jats:sub> ≅ − 1,8.</jats:p>

Title: Untersuchungen zur radikalischen Copolymerisation von Dimethyl‐diallyl‐ammoniumchlorid mit Vinylacetat und Funktionalisierungsreaktionen der Copolymere
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die radikalische Polymerisation von Dimethyl‐diallyl‐ammoniumchlorid mit Vinylacetat in methanolischer Lösung verläuft als nichtideale, nichtazeotrope Copolymerisation. Die nach der Kelen‐Tüdös‐Gleichung berechneten Reaktivitätsverhältnisse wurden zur <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,95 und <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,35 bestimmt. Die resultierenden Polymere sind relativ niedermolekular und im gesamten Zusammensetzungsbereich in Wasser löslich. An ausgewählten Copolymeren wurden Modifizierungsreaktionen wie Hydrolyse, Acetalisierung und Acylierung durchgeführt, die Produkte mit veränderten Eigenschaften ergaben.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity of some vinylimidazoles towards other vinyl monomers in radical copolymerization

Allylic Polymers II. Effects of Chloro-Substituents on Copolymerization of Allyl Chloroacetates with Vinyl Acetate
Syntheses and Polymerizations of Unsaturated Dibasic Acid Derivatives
Copolymers of vinylamine and vinylalcohol by acid hydrolysis of poly(N‐vinyl‐tert‐butylcarbamate‐co‐vinylacetate): Evaluation of reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of vinylamine and vinylalcohol were prepared by hydrolysis of poly(<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyltert‐butylcarbamate‐co‐vinylacetate) in 1:1 v/v % ethanol/HCl mixtures at room temperature. Reactivity ratios of the monomers <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐tert‐butylcarbamate (1) and vinylacetate (2) were calculated from monomer feed and copolymer composition data, according to the methods of Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdös, yielding <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.14 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.47 ± 0.07, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12 ± 0.07, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.03, respectively. From these values the average sequence length distribution of monomer units was derived showing that in the raction of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐tert‐butyl carbamate and vinylacetate nearly Bernouillian (i.e., purely random) copolymers are formed, with a slight tendency toward alternation.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Experimental study of copolymerization. III. Copolymerization behavior of polychloroethylenes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Experimental results are reported for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>‐ and <jats:italic>trans</jats:italic>‐dichloroethylenes and trichloroethylene with vinyl acetate and styrene. Unsymmetrical as well as symmetrical 1,2 polysubstituted ethylenes exhibit extremely small rate constants for self‐propagation, but are easily attacked by vinyl‐type radicals such as that formed by vinyl acetate. The attack of such monomers by vinyl “growing chain” radicals is retarded by substitution on the attacked carbon atom, but is favored by substitution on the other carbon atom of the double bond.</jats:p>

Title: Oligomerization and Copolymerization ofEndo-N-Benzylbicyclo[2,2,1]Hept-2-Ene-5,6-Dicarboximide
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Opening mode in the propagation of dialkyl fumarates and maleates as 1,2-disubstituted ethylenes in radical polymerization
Copolymerization of C‐vinyltriazoles and C‐vinyltetrazole with vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of 4(5)‐vinyl‐1,2,3‐triazole, 1‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐bromophenyl‐4‐vinyl‐1,2,3‐triazole and 2‐methyl‐5‐vinyltetrazole with styrene, methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate have been examined and the corresponding copolymerization parameters <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were evaluated. The reactivities <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> of these monomers are lower than that of styrene contrarily to other C‐vinylheterocyclic monomers; it is assumed that it results from a limited stabilization of the corresponding radicals. In the case of 4(5)‐vinyl‐1,2,3‐triazole, copolymerizations carried out at different temperatures and varied monomer concentrations show that intermolecular monomer association (as evidenced by NMR and IR measurements) does neither affect the copolymer composition nor the internal monomer triad structure of the copolymer.</jats:p>

Title: Unsaturated carbonic acid derivatives III. Copolymerization behavior of S‐, O‐ and N‐vinyl derivatives of carbonic acid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>S‐Vinyl‐N‐diethyl monothiolcarbamate, O‐Vinyl‐N‐diethyl carbamate, and N‐Vinyl‐N‐methyl‐S‐ethyl monothiocarbamate were copolymerized with styrene and vinyl acetate. The A<jats:sc>LFREY</jats:sc>‐P<jats:sc>RICE</jats:sc> Q‐ and e‐values were calculated and compared with those of other S, O, and N‐vinyl monomers. The S‐vinyl thiolcarbamate was found to be more reactive as a comonomer than the N‐ or O‐vinyl compounds.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate with four different monomers have been investigated, and the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> determined in the case of each comonomer pair. The monomers used were styrene, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and ethyl acrylate. From these data were calculated the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate. It is apparent that this monomer resembles ethyl acrylate very closely in its copolymerization characteristics.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 1‐acrylamido‐1‐deoxy‐Dhyphen;glucitol and of 1‐deoxy‐1‐methacrylamido‐D‐glucitol with various vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization characteristics for 1‐acrylamido‐1‐deoxy‐D‐glucitol and of 1‐deoxy‐1‐methacrylamido‐D‐glucitol with various vinyl monomers is given. For the former compounds <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values are found to be 0.12 and 0.6 respectively and, for the latter, 0.08 and 1.3. In addition, viscosity, osmotic molecular weights, and solubilities for representative compounds are given.</jats:p>

Title: Dérivés N‐Vinyliques IV. — Copolymérisation de la N‐Vinyl N‐Éthylurée
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>N‐vinyl‐N′‐ethylurea, a new monomer the synthesis of which has been reported previously, was copolymerized with vinylacetate. methylmethacrylate and styrene.</jats:p><jats:p>The Q and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated according to the Alfrey‐Price scheme:</jats:p><jats:p><jats:chem-struct-wrap><jats:chem-struct><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/must001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:chem-struct></jats:chem-struct-wrap></jats:p><jats:p>These values are in good agreement with those found for two other monomers which also have a –N–CO– substituent on a carbon atom of the double bond: N‐vinylpyrrolidone and ethyl‐N‐vinylcarbamate.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of sodium 2‐acrylamido‐2‐methyl‐propanesulfonate with vinyl acetate
Copolymerization of Ferrocenylmethyl Acrylate and Ferrocenylmethyl Methacrylate with Organic Monomers
Reactivity of N‐alkylated cyclic iminoether salts having vinyl groups, 2. Polymerization and copolymerization of 2‐isopropenyl‐3‐methyl‐2‐oxazolinium salts
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>3‐Methyl‐2‐isopropenyl‐2‐oxazolinium salts (<jats:bold>4a, b</jats:bold>) were prepared by alkylation of 2‐isopropenyl‐2‐oxazoline (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>). Their preparation is much easier than that of their vinyl analogues, 3‐methyl‐2‐vinyl‐2‐oxazolinium salts, which cannot be isolated due to their high tendency to polymerization. <jats:bold>4a</jats:bold>, however, was found, to show a low tendency toward radical and anionic polymerization, but it can be smoothly radically copolymerized with some vinyl monomers. The copolymerization parameters of <jats:bold>4a</jats:bold> were determined and discussed in comparison with those of <jats:bold>2</jats:bold>.</jats:p>

Title: A study of the relative reactivity of maleic anhydride and some maleimides in free radical copolymerization and terpolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Composition data for the free radical copolymerization of maleic anhydride with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide in toluene at 60°C have been obtained. Relative reactivity ratios in terminal and penultimate models using nonlinear least‐squares optimization routine have been determined. The standard error was found to be somewhat smaller in the penultimate model, but is still larger than the uncertainty estimated for the copolymer composition. Terpolymers of maleic anhydride and styrene with maleimide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐butylmaleimide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide, and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐carbamylmaleimide were obtained. On the basis of analysis of the product composition at various monomer feeds the relative reactivity of maleic anhydride and maleimides in these reactions is compared and the influence of the structure of thesemonomers on the rate of some chain growth reactions is discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Radical Terpolymerization of p-Dioxene, Maleic Anhydride and P-Chloroethyl Acrylate
