Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 5. Copolymerization of benzyl methacrylate with maleic anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of benzyl methacrylate (BMA) with maleic anhydride (MA), initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile at 70°C in chloroform or acetonitrile, were investigated. The complex formation between the two monomers in chloroform was studied by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The stability constant of the complex was found to be 0,25 l.mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The following copolymerization reactivity ratios were found: in chloroform: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>BMA</jats:sub> = 0,188 ± 0,035 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,003 ± 0,005, in acetonitrile: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>BMA</jats:sub> = 0,116 ± 0,093 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,231 ± 0,027. By <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR investigations it could be shown that the results correlate with the changes of the reactivity ratios depending on the solvent used.</jats:p>

Title: Ein beitrag zur kenntnis der N‐vinylimide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Die Darstellung von N‐Vinylsuccinimid, N‐Vinylphthalimid und 4‐Trimethylsilyl‐N‐vinylphthalimid durch Umvinylierung der Imide, durch alkalische Bromwasserstoffabspaltung aus N‐2‐Bromäthylimiden sowie durch katalytische Dehydratation von N‐2‐Hydroxyäthylimiden wurde untersucht; dabei wurden durchlaufene Zwischenstufen aufgeklärt.</jats:p><jats:p>Die Copolymerisationsparameter der folgenden Monomerenpaare wurden bestimmt und die Q‐ und e‐Werte berechnet: N‐Vinylsuccinimid/N‐Vinylcarbazol, N‐Vinylsuccinimid/Maleinsäureanhydrid, N‐Vinylsuccinimid/Maleinsäuredimethylester, N‐Vinylphthalimid/Maleinsäureanhydrid, 4‐Trimethylsilyl‐N‐vinylphthalimid/Styrol.</jats:p>

Title: Radical Polymerization of .alpha.-Methylenebenzocyclobutene, A Cyclic Analog of .alpha.-Methylstyrene
Mechanism of complex-radical copolymerization of maleic anhydride with monoallyl- and tri-n-butylstannylallyl maleates
Radiation‐induced copolymerization of isobutyl vinyl ether with trichloroethylene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radiation‐induced copolymerization of isobutyl vinyl ether with trichloroethylene was investigated in the temperature range from −50°C to 100°C over a wide range of comonomer compositions. A copolymer was obtained in which the monomers alternate with regularity along the polymer chain over essentially the entire range of comonomer compositions. Both the rate of copolymerization and the number‐average molecular weight of the resulting copolymer were found to depend strongly on the initial comonomer composition. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined and correspond well with calculated values. An apparent activation energy of 3.2 kcal/mole was obtained for the copolymerization process which exhibits a dose rate dependence of 0.72. The number‐average molecular weight was found to be strongly dependent on the irradiation temperature, reaching a maximum value at 5°C.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Polymers from 1,2-Disubstituted Ethylenic Monomers VI. Monomer-isomerization Radical Polymerization of Diethyl Maleate
Copolymerization of Styrene with Isobutyl Vinyl Ether by Radiation
Copolymerization of methacrylic anhydride with vinyl monomers
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of methacrylic anhydride and a variety of common types of vinyl monomers were conducted in bulk and in solution at 60–80° with benzoyl peroxide catalyst. The copolymers were characterized by conversion, solubility in hot dimethyl sulfoxide, elementary analysis, and infrared spectroscopy. A copolymer composition equation was derived for a special divinyl–vinyl system in which the divinyl monomer would cyclize extensively during polymerization and give rise to soluble, although perhaps branched, copolymers. The results showed that both soluble and insoluble copolymers were obtained, depending on the comonomer used and experimental conditions under which the copolymerization was carried out. In general, soluble copolymers were formed under the following conditions: (<jats:italic>a</jats:italic>) the less reactive the comonomer in free radical copolymerizations; (<jats:italic>b</jats:italic>) the greater the dilution; (<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>) the greater the difference in the moles of the two components in charge; and (<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>) the lower the conversion. According to reactivity ratio determinations and a comparison with published data, the anhydride ring radical behaved like a methyl methacrylate radical. The key step which led to gelation was believed to be “ring interruption” by the comonomer (CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = CHR):
<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/nust001.gif" xlink:title="chemical structure image" />
The question why methacrylic anhydride does not gel in homopolymerization, however, still remains unresolved.</jats:p>

Title: Studies in cyclocopolymerization. III. Copolymerization of divinyl ether with certain nitrogen‐containing alkenes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of divinyl ether with fumaronitrile (A), tetracyanoethylene (B), and 4‐vinylpyridine (C) has been studied, azobisisobutyronitrile being used as initiator. The compositions of the copolymers were calculated from their nitrogen and unsaturation content. Over a wide range of initial monomer composition, the mole fraction of A in the copolymers lies in the range 0.55–0.63, and the copolymers contained only 2–3% unsaturation, indicating a high degree of cyclization. The composition of the copolymers of B indicated that cyclization occurred to only a small extent, as the copolymers contained rather high unsaturation content. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.23 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.12 were obtained. The mole fraction of C in the copolymers lies between 0.85 and 0.998. If the assumption is made that <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ⋍ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> ⋍ 0 and there is predominant cyclization, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 32.0 in this case. The difference in the composition of the copolymers is attributed to the difference between the electron density of the double bonds in A, B, and C.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: The copolymerization of N-vinyl lactams with alkyl vinyl ethers
Kernresonanzspektroskopische mikrostrukturanalyse von vinylchlorid‐propen‐copolymeren, 2 NMR‐spektroskopische bestimmung der taxieparameter aus den häufigkeiten konfigurativer triaden
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymere aus Vinylchlorid (VC) und Propen (P) wurden durch hochauflösende magnetische Protonenresonanz bei 100 MHz untersucht. Die Methylresonanz der P‐Einheiten und die entkoppelte Methinresonanz der VC‐Einheiten konnten anhand eines graphischen Trennverfahrens konfigurativen Triaden zugeordnet werden.</jats:p><jats:p>Es wurde eine graphische Darstellung entwickelt, die sowohl die Werte der Cotaxieparameter Σ<jats:sub>s</jats:sub> und Σ<jats:sub>p</jats:sub> liefert als auch ein Test für das “ultimate model” ist. Aus der Abhängigkeit der Cotaxieparameter von der Polymerisationstemperatur konnten die Aktivierungsenthalpien der taktischen Wachstumsschritte ermittelt werden.</jats:p>

Title: Vinyl Polymerization
Radiation-Induced Copolymerization of Fluorine-Containing Monomers
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Radiation-Induced Copolymerization of Tetrafluoroethylene with Styrene
Studies of the polymerization of diallyl compounds. XXXVII. Copolymerizations of diallyl phthalate with dialkyl fumarates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Diallyl phthalate (DAP) was copolymerized with dialkyl fumarates, including diethyl fumarate (DEF), di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl fumarate (DBF), and di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octyl fumarate (DOF) by using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator at 60°C. Both rate and degree of copolymerization were quite enhanced compared with the homopolymerization of DAP and the maximum rate was found at the molar ratio of 1:1 in the monomer feed. The cyclization of DAP was almost exclusively suppressed in the Copolymerization. Gelation was promoted from 25% of the gel‐point conversion for the DAP homopolymerization to 9% of the minimum one observed. Copolymerizability of DAP (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with dialkyl fumarates (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was quite high, with the following monomer reactivity ratios M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>: DEF, 0.01, 1.25; DBF, 0.02, 1.01; DOF, 0.02, 0.96. These results are discussed in mechanistic detail.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Reactivity ratios of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl methacrylate copolymer system by 1H‐NMR
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl acrylate (EA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BMA) copolymers were prepared in solution and the composition of the copolymer samples was estimated by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopic techniques. Because the characteristic signals, which vary with the composition of the copolymer, were absent, the ratio of intensities of down‐field protons to that of the total protons was used for the estimation of copolymer composition. Reactivity ratios were calculated from these values by using the Kelen‐Tudos differential linear equation.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of acrylates and methacrylates by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy
The Relative Reactivities of Alkyl Acrylates in Their Radical Copolymerizations
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In order to clarify the effect of the alkyl groups in alkyl acrylates (RA) on their reactivities to the attack of a radical, the copolymerization of RA (M2) with styrene (M1) has been carried out at 60°C. From the results obtained, the monomer reactivity ratios and the Q2 and e2 values were determined. It was found that the relative reactivities (1/r1) of RA to a polystyryl radical were correlated only by the polar substituent constant (σ*) of the alkyl group in RA, not by their steric substituent constant (Es) in Taft’s equation:</jats:p>
               <jats:p>log(1⁄r1)=ρ*σ*+δEs</jats:p>
               <jats:p>According to the above equation, the ρ* and δ values were obtained as 0.56 and 0, respectively. It was also observed that the Q2 and e2 values for RA were correlated by Taft’s σ* substituent constant.</jats:p>
Journal: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan

Title: COPOLYMERIZATION OF ETHYLACRYLATE WITH 2-CHLOROETHYLVINYLETHER
Radical copolymerization of 2-hydroxyethylacrylate with alkylacrylate
Effect of temperature on the monomer reactivity ratios of 2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate with ethyl‐ and butyl‐acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate has been copolymerized with ethyl acrylate and n‐butyl acrylate in bulk at temperatures between 60 and 100°C using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The compositions of copolymers have been analyzed by hydroxyl determination; the reactivity ratios have been calculated by Kelen‐Tüdös method. Arrhenius parameters have been derived. The intrinsic viscosities and the thermal behaviours of the copolymers were also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization behaviour of N,N' — divinylureas
Copolymerization of 2-methacryloxytropone with methyl methacrylate and ethyl acrylate
Copolymerization behavior of 2‐vinylbenzofuran: Copolymers of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity of 2‐vinylbenzofuran in copolymerization reactions with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate was investigated. The vinylbenzofuran was found to be a very reactive monomer with the growing chain preferring to react with this monomer no matter what its terminus. Reactivity ratios were calculated using a nonlinear least squares error‐in‐variables method, which gives more reliable values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Random ethylacrylate-sulphonatopropylbetaine copolymers. 1. Synthesis and characterization
Copolymerization of glycidyl methacrylate with alkyl acrylate monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A newer approach to obtaining acrylic thermoset polymers with adequate hydrophilicity required for various specific end uses is reported. Glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) was copolymerized with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BA), isobutyl acrylate (<jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐BA), and 2‐ethylhexyl acrylate (2‐EHA) in bulk at 60°C. with benzoyl peroxide as free radical initiator. The copolymer composition was determined from the estimation of epoxy group. Reactivity ratios were calculated by the Yezrielev, Brokhina, and Roskin method. For copolymerization of GMA (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BA (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) the reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.15 ± 0.14, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.12 ± 0.03; with <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐BA (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) they were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.27 ± 0.06, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.33 ± 0.031; and with 2‐EHA (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) they were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.32 ± 0.14, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.13 ± 0.009. The reactivity ratios were the measure of distribution of monomer units in a copolymer chain; the values obtained are compared and discussed.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Copolymerization of 2‐hydroxypropyl methacrylate with alkyl acrylate monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate has been copolymerized with methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate in bulk at 60°C using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The compositions of copolymers have been determined by the estimation of the hydroxyl group by acetylation process. The copolymerization parameters have been determined by conventional scheme of copolymerization.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Organotin polymers. XI. Radical copolymerization reactions of di‐(tri‐n‐butyltin) itaconate with 2‐chloroethyl acrylate n‐butyl acrylate and allyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Di‐(tri‐n‐butyltin) itaconate was coplymerized with 2‐chloroethyl acrylate, n‐butyl acrylate and allyl methacrylate in solution at 70°C using AIBN as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization reactions have been determined. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for di‐(tri‐n‐butylin) itaconate as well as the sequence distribution of triad fractions for the azeotropic copolymers were calculated from the monomer reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: Contribution to the study of the kinetics of radical homo‐ and copolymerization of fluoroalkyl methacrylates, 1. 2‐chloro‐2,3,3,3‐tetrafluoropropyl methacrylate

Synthesis of substituted polymethylenes from acenaphthylene by radical polymerization and copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical polymerization of acenaphthylene (Ace) as a 1,2‐disubstituted ethylene was investigated. It was found that the polymerization rate (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) was expressed as follows: <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[Ace]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.68</jats:sup>, and that the overall activation energy was 113 kJ/mol for polymerization with 2,2'‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) in benzene at 50–70°C. Poly(Ace) obtained was characterized by NMR spectroscopy and GPC. Some substituted copolymethylenes were also prepared by radical copolymerization of Ace with other 1,2‐disubstituted ethylenes, that is, maleic anhydride, diisopropyl fumarate, and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐cyclohexylmaleimide. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined from comonomer–copolymer composition curves.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of optically active copolymers of acenaphthylene. 1. Preparation and characterization
Copolymerization of phenylacetylene with vinylpyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Experiments on the copolymerization of phenylacetylene with 2‐vinylpyridine gave values for the copolymerization ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4.0 ± 0.7 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20 ± 0.05. Estimates of the copolymerization constants, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.3 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.6, from these experiments agree with those estimated from values of copolymerization constants recently reported by Doak from studies of copolymerization of phenylacetylene with methyl acrylate and acrylonitrile. The experiments reported herein support the report by Doak that phenylacetylene acts as a marked retarder, as well as a commoner.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and properties of polymers containing phosphorus and nitrogen
Radiation-Initiated Codimerization of Methallyl Chloride with Unsaturates
NMR studies of free-radical polymerization and copolymerization of monomers and polymers containing allyl groups
Analysis of the linear methods for determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, VII. A critical reexamination of radical copolymerizations of styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios of 8000 published styrene copolymerization systems have been reviewed in terms of the extended Kelen‐Tüdős method. Only 649 systems were described in sufficient detail for reevaluation and classification. r‐Values, together with their 95% confidence limits have been calculated. Quantities δ□ and Q, suitable for classification of the systems, have been applied. Of the 649 reevaluated systems, 243 (37.5%) were found to belong to class I and 221 (34.1%) to class I(!), i.e. 464 (71.6%) systems for which the conventional copolymerization equation was found to be adequate. 66 (10.2%) class II systems were found where the two‐parameter model does not hold. Finally, 118 (18.2%) systems were judged to belong to class III, i.e. systems for which the experimental data are inconsistent and the published r‐values meaningless.</jats:p>

Title: 1-Chloro-1,3-butadiene Copolymers. III. Reactivity of 1-Chloro-1,3-butadiene in Radical Copolymerizations
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Radical copolymerizations of 1-chloro-1,3-butadiene (CB) were carried out with styrene (St), 1,3-butadiene (Bd), or chloroprene (Cp) in toluene at 70 °C by AIBN. The monomer reactivity ratios are found as follows: rCB=1.21±0.10, rSt=0.10±0.03; rCB=0.27±0.02, rBd=0.56±0.03. Copolymerization of CB and Cp showed CB was much less reactive than Cp. The Q and e values of CB were calculated to be 3.13 and +0.65, respectively. 1H NMR and IR of poly(CB-co-St) showed 60% of CB units are of 1,4-configuration and the rest 3,4-configuration.</jats:p>

Title: Graft copolymerization with perester side groups
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of the graft copolymerization of styrene onto methyl acrylate (MA) and methyl methacrylate copolymers (MMA) containing <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl perester groups have been studied. The synthesis of these perester copolymers was carried out in two steps: (<jats:italic>1</jats:italic>) copolymerization of acrylyl chloride with methyl (meth)acrylate, and (<jats:italic>2</jats:italic>) reaction of the acrylyl chloride copolymer with <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl hydroperoxide. Further, these perester copolymers were usually treated with diazomethane in order to methylate any carboxylic group which might be present. The graft copolymers were separated from both hompolymers by progressive precipitation on addition of methanol to the chloroform solution of the copolymers. The stability of these perester copolymers has been considered and found to depend on whether there are acid groups in the copolymer. The first‐order rate constants and the activation energy of decomposition in the absence of acid groups have been evaluated. These values depend on the molar composition of the copolymer; an induced decomposition of peresters is favored by a high perester content, which is responsible for a decrease in <jats:italic>E<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> (26.8 instead of 29.6 kcal./mole). In the presence of free carboxylic groups, some of the perester groups decompose very rapidly, the energy of activation of their decomposition being only 15 instead of 25.6 kcal./mole for the slow step. The degree of conversion attained during the rapid step is a function of the stereochemical structure of the copolymer, and the rate of decomposition is much higher than that produced by the addition of external acid. With the MA perester the rate of grafting is proportional to the square root of the perester concentration while it is first order with respect to the monomer concentration. These dependences were found to hold also for the overall rate of polymerization (from the total weight increase) as well as for the grafting rate (from the isolated graft copolymer and its styrene content). The styrene content of the graft copolymer increases with monomer concentration (e.g., 53.8 and 75.3 for monomer concentrations of 2.6 and 6.1 moles/l., respectively). At low monomer concentration, grafting is greatly favored over homopolymerization; it is also enhanced by the viscosity of the solution. With the MMA perester also, the grafting rate obeys the square root law for the perester concentration and the first‐order dependence on monomer. However, the rate of grafting is practically independent of the styrene concentration over a large range. The relative importance of grafting over homopolymerization is in this case much less than with MA‐TBP, except at high dilution. Different interpretations are suggested in order to explain the very high and sometimes very low values of <jats:italic>R<jats:sub>g</jats:sub>/R<jats:sub>h</jats:sub></jats:italic>, the ratio of the rate of grafting to the rate of hompolymerization. The different behaviors of the MA and MMA peresters are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acryloyl chloride with 2‐hydroxypropyl methacrylate
Graft efficiency
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Polystyrenes carrying <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl peracrylic side groups have been synthesized by copolymerization of styrene with acrylyl chloride, partial esterification of the acid chloride units with <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl hydroperoxide, and, finally, methylation of the remaining free carboxylic groups. The weight percent of perester units varied from 0.9 to 3.4, that of methyl acrylate between 14 and 18%. These copolymers were used at 75 °C. in benzene solution for initiating the polymerization of methyl methacrylate; this second step polymerization obeys the square‐root law with respect to the initiator concentration, and is proportional to the monomer concentration. The graft efficiency, <jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic> the ratio of the amount methyl methacrylate bonded as grafts to that of homopolymer, has been determined by carrying out fractionation of the several reaction products, using the precipitation method with chloroform as solvent and methanol as precipitant. The graft efficiency decreases from 1.52 to 0.77 when the monomer concentration increases from 1.91 to 7.54 mole· 1<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>; it is however unsensitive to the macroinitiator concentration, unsensitive to the bulk viscosity of the reaction medium as well as to the presence of non‐solvent (methanol) in this medium.</jats:p><jats:p>The perester‐content of the macroinitiator exerces a slight influence, the efficiency being higher when this content increases.</jats:p><jats:p>The temperature affects strongly the efficiency ratio; this ratio increases from 0.53 to 1.11 when the temperature rises from 55 ° to 75 °C.; this effect stresses the strong influence of the nature of the radical with respect to their ability of monomer addition.</jats:p>

Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 8. Copolymerization of monomethyl itaconate with 2‐naphthyl methacrylate
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of monomethyl itaconate (monomethyl 2‐methylenesuccinate, MMI) with 2‐naphthyl methacrylate (2‐NM) initiated with 2, 2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) in solvents of different dielectric constants and capability to form hydrogen bonds was investigated. The reactivity ratios of the monomer pairs in the different solvents are as follows:
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula></jats:p><jats:p>IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy studies show the influence of the solvent on the capability of the monomers to form hydrogen bonds and donor‐acceptor associates. The changes in the reactivity ratios of both monomers are attributed to the interaction observed between the monomer molecules as well as between the molecules of the monomers ad the respective solvent.</jats:p>

Title: Organotin polymers.I. Copolymerization on tributyltin methacrylate with (hydroxy) alkyl methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of tributyltin methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with cyclohexyl methacrylate, ethoxyethyl methacrylate, ethyl methacrylate, 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate, and 2‐hydroxypropyl methacrylate were synthesized in solution at 55°C utilizing azobisisobutyronitrile initiator. Copolymer compositions were determined by tin analysis; monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by Kelen‐Tüdös method. Since the reactivity ratios indicate the distribution of different monomer units in the polymer chain, the measured values are compared and discussed. Preliminary results of the biotoxicity studies on some of the copolymers are also reported.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Copolymerization of vinylene carbonate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of vinylene carbonate VC (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with several vinyl monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) has been examined. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> have been determined in the system VC‐vinyl acetate (0.27 and 3.0), VC‐vinyl chloride (0.09 and 5.2), VC‐vinylpyrrolidone (0.4 and 0.7), VC‐methyl methacrylate (<0.01 and ∼70). These values indicate for vinylene carbonate in the Alfrey‐Price scheme a reactivity <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> equal to 0.012 and a polarity <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> of −0.6. From the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> parameters of the system vinyl acetatevinylpyrrolidone (0.38 and 0.44, respectively) the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of vinylpyrrolidone have also been determined: <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.11 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −1.6. The copolymers of vinylene carbonate and vinyl acetate yield on hydrolysis polyalcohols (CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CHOH)<jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic></jats:sub>(CHOH)<jats:sub><jats:italic>y</jats:italic></jats:sub> of which the solubility decreases with increasing content of hydroxyl groups.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization characteristics of vinylene carbonate, γ‐crotonolactone and methyl bicyclo(2,2,1)‐2‐heptene‐5‐carboxylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of three cyclic vinylene monomers has been investigated. For vinylene carbonate, we found <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.005, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.8, and for methyl bicyclo(2,2,1)‐2‐heptene‐5‐carboxylate, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.02, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.0. A convenient preparation of γ‐crotonolactone is reported, but no satisfactory copolymerization for this material was found.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent Effects in Radical Copolymerization between Hydrophilic and Hydrophobic Monomers; 2-Hydroxyethyl Methacrylate and Lauryl Methacrylate

Hydroxyalkyl methacrylates: Kinetic investigations of radical polymerizations of pure 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate and 2, 3-dihydroxypropyl methacrylate and the radical copolymerization of their mixtures
Free radical copolymerization of furfuryl acrylate and 2‐hydroxyethyl‐methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of furfuryl acrylate (<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) were prepared by free radical polymerization in DMF solution at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of both monomers were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös linearization methods, as well as the Tidwell and Mortimer nonlinear least‐squares treatment. The reactivity ratios obtained were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>F</jats:sub> = 0.93 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1.42. The microstructure of copolymer chains is described on the basis of first‐order Markov statistics, and the copolymer glass transition temperatures were determined calorimetrically. The variation of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> with the copolymer composition is discussed according to modern methods, considering the sequence distribution of monomeric units along the copolymer chains. Also the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding homopolymers was determined giving the values <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) = 321 K and <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) = 358 K, whereas the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating diad has an average value of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic>FH</jats:sub> = 326 K. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Radikalische Copolymerisation von p-Chlorstyrol und n-Butylmethacrylat
Polymérisation et copolymérisation du m‐nitrostyrène
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>La polymérisation du méta‐nitrostyrène est caractérisé par une vitesse de polymérisation proportionelle à la concentration en intiateur utilisée; ce comportement s'interprête par un transfert de chaïne désactivant, dû à la présence d'un groupe nitré dans le noyau benzénique.</jats:p><jats:p>De même que les polymères, les copolymères, obtenus au départ de <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐nitrostyrène et de styrène, méthacrylate de méthyle ou chlorostyrène, ont toujours un poids moléculaire très bas; la validité du schéma habituel de la copolymérisation dans ce cas particulier est discutée. Les valeurs apparentes de r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> et de r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> sont indiquées pour les différents systèmes de monomères étudiés.</jats:p>
Journal: Recueil des Travaux Chimiques des Pays-Bas

Title: Radical copolymerization of crotonyl compounds with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for the radical copolymerization of crotononitrile (CN), methyl crotonate (MC), and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐propenyl methyl ketone (PMK) with styrene (St) were measured at 60°C. in benzene and little penultimate unit effect was shown for these systems. The values obtained were: St–CN, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 24.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0; St–MC, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 26.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01; St–PMK, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 13.7, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01. The rate of copolymerization and the viscosity of the copolymer decreased markedly as the molar fraction of the crotonyl compound in the monomer mixture increased. The <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> values were also calculated to be as follows: CN, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.13, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.009; MC, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.36, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.015; PMK, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.61, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.024. A linear relationship was obtained between the <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of the crotonyl compounds and their Hammett constants σ<jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Glycidyl methacrylate–tert‐butyl acrylate copolymers: Synthesis, characterization, and thermal studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Glycidyl methacrylate was copolymerized with tert‐butyl acrylate in bulk at 60°C using benzoyl peroxide as free radical initiator. The copolymer composition was determined by chemical analysis as well as from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by using the YBR method. The number average sequence length of the copolymers was determined from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data and compared with those obtained from reactivity ratios. The intrinsic viscosity of the copolymers was determined in DMF, and thermal stability as well as mechanism of thermal degradation of the copolymers were evaluated.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Water-soluble copolymers. 14. Potentiometric and turbidimetric studies of water-soluble copolymers of acrylamide: comparison of carboxylated and sulfonated copolymers
Copolymers of 2‐vinyl‐4,4‐dimethylazlactone with styrene and ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for copolymerization of 2‐vinyl‐4,4‐dimethylazlactone (VA) and ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate (EHMA) were 0.20–0.24 and 0.53–0.74, respectively, which show that EHMA is slightly more reactive with VA than with itself and should lead to random copolymers favoring alternation. The VA–styrene (VA–St) system also has a tendency to form random copolymers but with increased tendency for alternation with both <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> between 0.18–0.22. <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>'s of VA–EHMA and VA–St copolymers varied between 100 and 136°C, and 96 and 117°C, respectively. Thermolysis of VA–EHMA copolymers resulted in crosslinking via the ring‐opening reaction of VA groups by EHMA alcohols, followed by transesterification involving EHMA units at higher temperatures leading to highly crosslinked structures. The performed dimer of EHMA and VA was also synthesized and found to be an effective crosslinking agent in free radical vinyl polymerizations.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Thermal degradation of polymethacrylonitrile. Part II. The coloration reaction
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The thermal coloration which occurs in copolymers of methacrylonitrile with small amounts of methacrylic acid has been studied at 140°C. The infrared spectra of colored polymers show a decrease in nitrile absorption (which has been followed quantitatively) and new absorption appears, mainly at 1693–1490 cm.<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> No volatile material is lost during coloration and molecular weight measurements show that neither chain scission nor crosslinking is involved. Copolymers of different compositions have been used to control the length of sequences of adjacent methacrylonitrile units, and it has been found that coloration is inhibited by larger concentrations of methacrylic acid. Colored polymer slowly reverts to the original material in solution, and rapid decoloration is effected by addition of aqueous solutions of acids, alkalis, and salts. A structure has been deduced for colored polymethacrylonitrile analogous to those proposed previously for paracyanogen and colored polyacrylonitrile. Essentially this is the results of the linking up of adjacent nitrile groups to form conjugated carbon‐nitrogen sequences of considerable length. It is suggested that this structure is formed in a nonradical chain process initiated at methacrylic acid units and propagated through adjacent nitrile units. The changes in solubility properties are not the result of crosslinking but of the rigidity of the modified polymer structure.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerisation of vinylidene chloride and methacrylonitrile, 1. Sequence microstructure measured by 220 MHz <sup>1</sup>H NMR
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerisation of vinylidene chloride and methacrylonitrile in bulk and in cyclohexanone solution was studied. The monomer dyad sequence distributions and some of the tetrad and hexad sequences were obtained from 220 MHz <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectra of the copolymers. From the copolymer compositions and sequence information it could be shown that the copolymerisation kinetics deviate from the simple Mayo‐Lewis scheme. Small differences were found between the bulk and solution copolymerisations.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic acid esters with methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of methacrylonitrile with styrene, methacrylic acid, and eleven alkyl methacrylates have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:bold>e</jats:bold> values calculated. Monomer reactivity in these systems is principally a function of resonance stabilization (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>), polar factors (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) playing a relatively minor role. With the exception of the stearyl ester, the changes in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values which occur on ascending the homologous series can be accounted for qualitatively in terms of the expected relative electronic displacements and of the steric effects caused by the various alkyl groups. Some correlation between monomer reactivity and the depolymerizability of the corresponding polymer has been noted.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. V. Relative Monomer Addition Rates in Vinyl Copolymerization
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Plasma-induced polymerization
Cyclopolymerization. V. Copolymerization of acrylic and methacrylic anhydrides with vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of acrylic (AA) and methacrylic (MAA) anhydrides (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with styrene (St) and methacrylonitrile (MAN) have been examined; similarly that of acrylic anhydride with allyl chloride. In these systems the reactivity ratio of an open unit radical (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) is equal to that of a cyclized radical (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub>), and the usual Alfrey‐Price equation is valid. By using a graphical method the ratios of the cross propagation rate constant to the cyclization rate constant (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub>) have been also evaluated. The following values for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> respectively have been found, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> being the anhydride: for the system AA (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–St, 0.1, 0.17, and 4; for the system AA–MAN, 0.9, 0.04, and 0.14; for the system AA–allyl chloride, 11.5, 0.01, and 0. For the same systems with MAA, the values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> were 0.26, 0.12, and 0.2 with St, and 1.6, 0.27, and about zero with MAN. These data indicate also that the cyclization reaction is always more pronounced for methacrylic anhydride than for the acrylic anhydride.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: Cyclopolymerization. III. Kinetics of polymerization and copolymerization of vinyl‐trans‐cinnamate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of cyclopolymerization and cyclo‐copolymerization of vinyl cinnamate were studied. The mechanism of chain propagation during the cyclopolymerization of vinyl cinnamate was considered. By determination of the residual unsaturation of the polymer (I.R. and U.V. spectrometry and bromometry) at different monomer concentrations, it was possible to evaluate the ratio of the cyclization rate constant to the vinyl propagation rate constant; it is equal to 13.</jats:p><jats:p>In the range of low monomer concentrations the polymerization of vinyl cinnamate is of first order with respect to monomer concentration, and of one half order with respect to initiator concentration. At monomer concentration higher than three mole·1.<jats:sup>minus;1</jats:sup> the reaction becomes independent of monomer concentration, and first order with respect to the initiator.</jats:p><jats:p>Modified copolymer composition equations were derived taking due account of the different reactivity of the monomer radical before and after cyclization; consequently three reactivity ratios r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and r<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> have been defined, and the experimental methods for their evaluation determined.</jats:p><jats:p>On the basis of these equations the following reactivity ratios have been evaluated: vinyl cinnamate(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)‐vinyl acetate r<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> = 1.2 ± 0.1 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.04; M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐vinyl pyrrolidone r<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> = 1.15–1.30 and r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.01; M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐methacrylonitrile r<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> = 0.15 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4; M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐styrene r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.25 ± 0.1 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.25 ± 0.1. The interpretation of these data suggests formation of a pseudo‐cyclic benzyl radical stabilized by resonance before addition of the second vinyl monomer.</jats:p>

Title: Dilatometric study of the solution copolymerization of 1,1,5-trihydroperfluoroamyl acrylate and methacrylonitrile
Synthesis of poly(chloroprene‐co‐isobutyl methacrylate) and its compatibilizing effect in polychloroprene/poly(isobutyl methacrylate) blends
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A copolymer of chloroprene (CP) and isobutyl methacrylate (iBMA) [poly(CP‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐iBMA)] was prepared in benzene by radical copolymerization. For comparison, the graft copolymer of iBMA onto polychloroprene (CR) [poly(CR‐<jats:italic>g</jats:italic>‐iBMA)] was also prepared. The glass transition temperature of the poly(CP‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐iBMA) was about −32.4°C. The monomer reactivity ratios determined by the Finneman‐Ross method were given as r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (CP) = 1.80 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (iBMA) = 0.74 in the copolymerization of CP and iBMA, respectively. Miscibility of blends of CR and poly(isobutyl methacrylate) (PiBMA), prepared by casting from tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution, was investigated by their glass transition temperature behaviors and morphologies. Although the blends of CR and PiBMA were incompatible, the addition of poly(CP‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐iBMA) or poly(CR‐<jats:italic>g</jats:italic>‐iBMA) enhanced miscibility between the two base polymers. It was found that the extent of partial miscibility becomes larger when adding poly(CP‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐iBMA) than poly(CR‐<jats:italic>g</jats:italic>‐iBMA) as a third component to the CR/PiBMA blend of 50/50 wt % composition. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Compounds with Dienes<sup>1</sup>
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Characterization of chloroprene and maleic anhydride copolymer by <sup>13</sup>C‐NMR spectroscopy and pyrolysis GC/MS
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerizations of chloroprene (CP) and maleic anhydride (MAH) were carried out with AIBN in 1,4‐dioxane at 60°C. The monomer reactivity ratios were estimated as r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (CP) = 0.38 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (MAH) = 0.07. Microstructures in the copolymer of chloroprene (CP) and maleic anhydride (MAH) were investigated by 75.4 MHz <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐and 300 MHz <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopies. Resonances were assigned to the monomer sequence dyads CC, CM, and MC (C = chloroprene, M = maleic anhydride). Well resolved fine structure in the <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra showed that 1,2‐ and 3,4‐structural chloroprene units were negligible in the copolymer. The pyrolysis characterization of the copolymer was also investigated by the pyrolysis gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC/MS). The fragments of CP and MAH monomers and CP‐MAH hybrid dimer, CO, and CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were identified after pyrolysis of the copolymer. © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Polymerisation radicalaire du penta-1,3-diene—V. Copolymerisation du penta-1,3-diene trans avec le methacrylate de methyle
Copolymerization of ethylene with the diethyl and diphenyl esters of vinylphosphinic acid
Copolymerization of the silane‐modified polyvinylimidazole(1) as a metal corrosion inhibitor
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of vinyl imidazole (VI) with γ‐methacryloxypropyltrimethoxy silane (γ‐MPS) by using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator was carried out in benzene at 68°C. The copolymer compositions at various monomer feeds were investigated by elemental analysis. The reactivity ratios of two monomers were determined by the Finemann‐Ross method: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>(VI) = 0.22, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (γ‐MPS) = 3.18. From these results, it could be concluded that silane‐modified polyvinylimidazoles were random copolymers (0<<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub><1). Thermal stability of decomposition of the copolymer increased with increasing the mole ratio of VI in the copolymer. Thermal decomposition of the copolymer was caused by the decomposition of the γ‐MPS unit. However, thermal stability above 300°C and maximum thermal decomposition temperature increased with increasing the mole ratio of γ‐MPS due to the crosslinking reaction of hydrolyzed γ‐MPS unit. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization Behavior of N-Vinylimidazole with Various Diaikyl Maleates and Fumarates
Journal: Journal of Macromolecular Science: Part A - Chemistry

Title: Radical copolymerization of 1-vinylimidazole and methacryl- or styryl-functional silane coupling agents
Copolymerization of N-vinyllactams with vinylphenyl and vinylcyclohexyl ethers
Copolymerization of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione with p‐chlorostyrene and vinylidene chloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene and vinylidene chloride is reported. The copolymers were prepared in sealed tubes under nitrogen with azobisisobutyronitrile initiator. Infrared absorption bands at 1580 cm.<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> revealed the presence of a highly enolic β‐diketone and indicated that copolymerization had occurred. The copolymer compositions were determined from the chlorine analyses and the reactivity ratios were evaluated. The copolymerization with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) was highly alternating and provided the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.32 ± 0.06, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.02 ± 0.01. Copolymerization with vinylidene chloride (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) afforded the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.4 ± 0.6, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.15 ± 0.05. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for the dione (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.13, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.37), as evaluated from the results of the vinylidene chloride case, agree closely with the previously reported results of copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and acrylonitrile and confirm the general low reactivity of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione in nonalternating systems.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A-1: Polymer Chemistry

Title: Copolymerization of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of 4‐cyclopentene‐1,3‐dione (D) with styrene (S) is reported. The copolymers were prepared by heating sealed tubes containing the monomer feeds and azobisisobutyronitrile. The copolymers exhibited infrared bands for the phenyl and β‐diketone groups, indicating that copolymerization had occurred. The copolymers were completely insoluble in all solvents. Some swelling was observed in tetrahydrofuran, nitrobenzene, and aqueous sodium hydroxide. From the compositions of the copolymers, as determined from the carbon and hydrogen analyses, it was found that the copolymers were about 40 mole‐% styrene over an appreciable range of feed compositions (0.1–0.6 mole fraction styrene). The results at styrene feeds <0.5 were in general agreement with the equation: <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[D]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[S] = 1 1/2 + (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>DD</jats:sub>/2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>DC</jats:sub><jats:italic>K</jats:italic>[S]). This equation was derived on the basis of monomer complex (C) participating in the propagation and a penultimate effect preventing the occurrence of a sequence of three dione units.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science Part A: General Papers

Title: An ESR study on the radical copolymerization of N-cyclohexylmaleimide and di-n-butyl itaconate in benzene
Structure and reactivities of alkyl vinyl ketones in their radical copolymerizations with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To clarify the effect of the alkyl substituents in alkyl vinyl ketones (RVK) on their radical copolymerizations, the copolymerizations of six such alkyl vinyl ketones with styrene were investigated. From the results obtained, the relative reactivities of RVK toward the polystyryl radical were correlated with the Taft equation: log (1/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) = ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup>σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> + δ<jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>s</jats:sub>, in which σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>s</jats:sub> are polar and steric substituent constants, respectively, and ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and δ are reaction constants. The values of ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and δ obtained were 0.40 ± 0.05 and 0, respectively. It was observed that the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values obtained for RVK increased with increasing of σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> values, and that both relative reactivities and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of methyl vinyl ketone also increased with increasing of the <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>T</jats:sub> values of the solvents used. From the spectral determination of the RVK monomers, it was also found that their <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>–π interactions were related to the copolymerization reactivities. Furthermore, the radical polymerization of <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl vinyl ketone (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BVK) with azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was investigated, and its rate <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> was found to be expressed by the following rate equation: <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic> [AIBN]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup>[<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BVK]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup>.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Kinetic and ESR studies on radical polymerization. ESR and kinetic evidences for the penultimate effect in the radical‐initiated copolymerization of N‐cyclohexylmaleimide and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐cyclohexylmaleimide (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with dimethyl 2,2′‐azoisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) as an initiator was carried out at 50°C in benzene. Monomer reactivity ratios were estimated as <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,34 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,38. The copolymerization rate (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and the molecular weight of the resulting copolymer increased with increasing concentration of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> when the total concentration of comonomers was fixed at 1,00 mol. L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> was proportional to [<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>]<jats:sup>0,5</jats:sup>, indicating a usual bimolecular termination in the copolymerization. An electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrum of the propagating polymer radicals was observable in the actual copolymerization system at 50°C. The spectrum of the copolymerization system is inexplicable in terms of any superposition of spectra observed in the corresponding homopolymerization systems, revealing that some penultimate monomeric unit causes a change in the ESR spectrum, that is, the structure of propagating polymer radical. The apparent rate constant of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) were estimated by ESR. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> values (1,5–50 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) are fairly higher than those estimated on the basis of the terminal model, affording another piece of evidence for the penultimate effect. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> value (1,8–5,4·10<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) shows a behaviour similar to that of the intrinsic viscosity of the resulting copolymer on varying the monomer feed composition, which seems to reflect diffusion‐control of termination reactions.</jats:p>

Title: Intramolecular charge transfer complexes
Synthesis, polymerization, and copolymerization of vinyl thioacetate
Kinetic and electron paramagnetic resonance studies on radical polymerization. Radical copolymerization of p‐tert‐butoxy‐styrene and dibutyl fumarate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butoxystyrene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and dibutyl fumarate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) initiated with dimethyl 2,2′‐azobisisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) was studied in benzene at 60°C kinetically and by means of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,18 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,01, indicating that homopropagation of M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is almost negligible in the copolymerization. The copolymerization system was revealed to involve EPR‐observable propagating polymer radicals under practical copolymerization conditions. The apparent rate constants of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub>) determined by EPR show a rapid increase in the range from 0,9 to 1,0 of feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = {[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>] + [M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])}) of M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>. From the relationship between <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> based on Fukuda's penultimate model, the rate constants of propagation of copolymerization were evaluated; <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>111</jats:sub> = 140 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>211</jats:sub> = 4,3 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>112</jats:sub> = 778 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>212</jats:sub> = 24 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and k<jats:sub>121</jats:sub> = 19 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, suggesting a pronounced penultimate effect.</jats:p>

Title: High Pressure Copolymerization of Styrene and Crotonaldehyde
Journal: The Journal of the Society of Chemical Industry, Japan

Title: Copolymerization of crotonic acid with vinylpyrrolidone
Reactivity of polar monomers in copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>As a consequence of earlier establishment of electrostatic repulsion between nonterminal polar 1,2‐disubstituted olefins in polymers and like adding monomer, polar methylenic monomers were examined for such an effect. Acrylonitrile was found to exhibit such behavior in at least three systems: styrene–acrylonitrile, α‐methylstyrene–acrylonitrile, and α‐acetoxystyrene–acrylonitrile. Absence of such an effect was shown for methacrylonitrile, methyl acrylate, acrylic acid, methacrylic acid, and crotonic acid. A modified copolymerization equation involving <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00223832:media:POL120147308:tex2gif-stack-1" />, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was presented. A convenient means of estimating <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in this equation as well as in the ordinary copolymerization equation was shown.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization characteristics of fumaronitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of fumaronitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) gave the following values for characteristic copolymerization constants: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.23 ± 0.1; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01 ± 0.01; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.6; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.6. With methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) the values were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.5 ± 0.5; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01 ± 0.01; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.4; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.0.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. VIII. Reactivity of Fumaronitrile in Vinyl Copolymerization
Journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Title: Solvent effects on radical homo‐ and copolymerizations of methacryloyl fluroride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The effect of solvent in homo‐ and copolymerizations of methacryloyl fluoride (MAF) was investigated in various aromatic solvents. In these solvents, there is a significant effect on the rate of polymerization, on the tacticity of the resulting poly(methacryloyl fluoride), and on the copolymerization of MAF with methyl methacrylate (MMA). The equilibrium constants between MAF and aromatic solvents were determined from NMR spectroscopic measurements. These results indicated that the solvent effect on the MAF polymerization stems from changes in reactivity of MAF induced by the strong MAF–solvent interaction as well as stabilization of the MAF radical by solvents. Copolymerization of MAF with both <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐methoxystyrene (MSt) and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐nitrostyrene (NSt) was also studied.</jats:p>
Journal: Journal of Polymer Science: Polymer Chemistry Edition

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerizations of methacryloyl fluoride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of methacryloyl fluoride (MAF) homopolymerization was investigated in methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) followed the expression <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.55</jats:sup>[MAF]<jats:sup>1.18</jats:sup>. The overall activation energy was calculated as 74.4 kJ/mol. The relative reactivity ratios of MAF(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.083, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.14), and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.48, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.81) in methyl ethyl ketone were obtained. Application of the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme (in styrene copolymerization) led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.22 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.31. The glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of poly(MAF) was 90°C by thermomechanical analysis. Thermogravimetry of poly(MAF) showed a 10% weight loss of 228°C in air.</jats:p>

Title: Radical polymerization and copolymerization of bis{3‐[tris(trimethylsiloxy)silyl]propyl} fumarate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical polymerization and copolymerization of bis{3‐[tris(trimethylsiloxy)silyl]propyl} fumarate (BSPF (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>)) were investigated. The reactivity of BSPF in homopolymerization was found to be very low, and only low‐molecular‐weight poly(BSPF) was obtained in low yields. On the other hand, copolymerizations of BSPF with diisopropyl fumarate (DiPF) and di‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl fumarate (DtBF) proceed with moderate rates to give high‐molecular‐weight copolymers. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be as follows; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,07, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,87 for BSPF (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and DiPF (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>); <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,21, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,67 for BSPF (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and DtBF (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>). The resulting copolymers are soluble in many common organic solvents. Tough and brittle films were obtained by solution casting of the copolymers of BSPF and DtBF. The copolymers exhibit excellent oxygen permeability.</jats:p>

Title: A re-evaluation of the reactivity ratios of 3-vinyl thiopene in copolymerization with butyl acrylate and methyl methacrylate
Dérivés N‐vinyliques II. Copolymérisation de l'isocyanate d'isopropényle
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Isopropenyl isocyanate was copolymerised with methyl acrylate and styrene. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> are calculated: methyl acrylate — isopropenyl isocyanate <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.8<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.08. styrene — isopropenyl isocyanate <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> — 7<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> — 0.14.</jats:p><jats:p>These results are discussed according to the theory of Alfrey and Price. The isocyanate group acts as an electron donor. This is in agreement with the mesomeric structures usually assigned to the aliphatic isocyanates.</jats:p>
